CANADA
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant No.66-2-S with certificate No. 5 properly filled in for payment to Mr Bowlin on account of his work on the combine teacher's residence and hospital, Tobique, N.B.

I beg to inform the Department that Mr Bowlin has the interior of the building all completed very satisfactory, and I would recommend him an advance of $2,000 on his contract, which I beg to submit herewith certificate No.5 for that amount.

I beg to inform the Department that all the work that remains to done to complete the contract, is the painting of the building on the exterior and the grading off the ground to make the proper drainage around the building, this will be done as soon as the weather permits.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 29, 1924.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant enclosing accounts from Mr. G. W. Larlee for $335.85 for extra electrical wiring provided at the combined hospital and teachers' residence, Tobique, N.B. This work was authorized some time ago, and was to have been added as an extra to the contract for the building. When submitting your next certificate form for payment on the contract this amount should be indicated in the space provided for "Extras".

I am returning herewith the accounts submitted.

With reference to the fifth certificate this has been reduced from $2,000 to $1,000. If you will read the specifications you will find that ten per cent of the contract price is to be withheld until the satisfactory completion of the work. This amount added to the allowance for the uncompleted work makes it necessary to reduce the certificate to $1,000.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. McLennan
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

C. J. Roberts, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Red Rapids,
N.B.

Please ship to my, our, address as soon as possible in the regular course of your business from ... the following goods at the prices end upon the terms hereinafter mentioned and now agreed upon free on board:

[Handwritten text not legible]

for which I, agree to pay you the sum of ... dollars as follows: $... each on said order.

Dollars, and the balance on receipt of the goods herein mentioned, which I agree to sign upon shipment, but before taking delivery of the aforesaid goods, said note to bear interest at seven per cent until payment.

It is hereby agreed that any portion of the price not paid in cash at time of delivery to bear interest at seven per cent per annum until payment by me or mine.

In case I fail to pay said bills at the times herein specified, I consent to your selling said goods or goods as security thereof, and agreeing to pay any liens which may thereafter be put against such goods, provided, however, that all payments made thereon shall be credited to you, and any balance due between me and you shall be treated as an entirely separate transaction.

Further, I agree that all cost and expenses incurred by you in connection therewith, including costs of sale and fees of any kind, shall be charged against me and be paid by me within ten days after written demand therefor, and if I fail so to pay same, you and any assignee or successor in title thereof may sell said goods or goods as security thereof, and I hereby acknowledge receipt of your notice, and declare that the same will become null and void notwithstanding that said note or notes for the said price or part thereof shall be annulled, discharged, or otherwise weakened or defeated, or partnership dissolution, insolvency, death, succession, change of name, or any other cause whatsoever, and further agree that I will be bound by all such agreements and will in all cases that may arise cause, matter, or thing connected therewith, whether originally or by way of substitution or addition, and with that object in view, you shall have the entire right to enter any of my, our premises to search for or to remove the same from thereon using whatever force or means may be necessary, and if such premises happen to be occupied without your consent, I agree to pay you damages for such occupation.

Furthermore, I agree that you may, at any time before such goods shall be sold, give credit to me for all consideration paid or deposited by me therefor, and any credit so given shall not be recoverable by me; but shall belong absolutely to you as rent or revenue.

In case said goods should be re-sold by you after your resale and shall become unsalable by reason of delay, defect, or other cause, you shall have the right to re-sell the same, and you may thereafter, as often as you see fit, without any further notice to me, resell or otherwise dispose of such goods, and may thereafter do so again and again, without any further notice to me, such goods at any time so re-sold and without holding any period of time over them, and such re-purchase or re-sale shall in no way act as a recission of this contract, nor shall it in any way affect or impair any part thereof. In case said goods are re-sold by you, on the latter date mentioned, we shall receive credit on the whole of said price for the pre-mentioned condition, and such price to be paid, by adding the amount thereof, the balance due out of said previous item, as above stated, shall be liable to be paid by me.

I, we, further agree that until payment in cash in full of said goods, the same shall be at my risk, and that you may, at any time before such goods shall be sold, stop and arrest the same as goods connected therewith, whether originally or by way of substitution or addition, and with that object in view, you shall have the entire right to enter any of my, our premises to search for or remove the same from thereon using whatever force or means may be necessary.

If any part of said goods be damaged, defective, or otherwise unfit for use or consumption, you shall have the right to repair or replace the same, expense made therefor to be charged against me, and if I fail to make any allowance for repairs or alterations unless same are made with your written consent or approval received from me in writing, you shall be entitled to deduct from said price the actual cost of materials used in making said repairs or alterations unless same are made with your written consent or approval received from me in writing, you shall be entitled to deduct from said price the actual cost of materials used in making said repairs or alterations unless same are made with your written consent or approval received from me in writing, you shall be entitled to deduct from said price the actual cost of materials used in making said repairs or alterations.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of October 10th, 1923, I beg to advise the Department that I placed a signed order dated October 25th for the water system to be installed in the combine teachers residence and hospital on the Tobique Reserve as outlined by Mr Wright agent for the Canadian Fair-Banks Morse Co., St John, N.B.

I beg to inform the Department that the water system was installed last November, and it was put into operation, and no doubt the system would give perfect satisfaction, but it was then found that we did not have a sufficient supply of water coming into the well, and it was decided that the well had to be drilled a further dept, which at the present I am having done, expect to have it finished in a few days, and as soon as the well is completed I will have the Canadian Fair-Banks Morse put their Pumping outfit into operation and if it works satisfactory I will recommend it for payment.

I beg to advise the Department that the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse has decided not to give any further time for settlement, and I inclose herewith a letter to me from their lawyers claiming to take immediate legal steps to collect same.

I also inclose the sign contract which does not give any date or how it was to be settled for.

Kindly advise in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Asst, Deputy and Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

April 26th, 1924.

Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

As you have been previously advised Reverend Father Hugolin Lemay former superior of Maliseet Reserve has resigned, and I have been appointed by the Ecclesiastical authorities to replace him. My nomination dates from April 1st, 1924, and I would be pleased if you would have my name inscribed as superior of the Indian Reserve, Tobique Point.

(Sgd.) Rev. J. Silvester, O.F.M.

NOTE: The Bishop of Chatham has approved of the appointment of Rev. Father Silvester to succeed Rev. Father Hugolin from the 1st of April, 1924, as missionary at Tobique.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of March 31st ult., No66-2-8 with reference to drilling of well a further depth in order to secure a sufficient supply of water for the combine teachers residence and hospital.

I beg to inform the Department that after starting to drill it was found necessary to draw the 54 feet of well casing and the well had to be drilled over again, the casing was bent in at the bottom and would not allow the sand pump to work, so the casing had to be drawn out of the well, and a six inch piece cut off that was battered and bent, the well then had to be drilled out again and this casing driven down, it was a very hard job to draw the casing, it had to be done with jack screws and it was a very slow but powerful process, but this was the only remedy in this case.

The casing only had to be driven a depth of about 60 ft, when we discovered ledge, and now the drillers are down 30 feet in the ledge, and they have not got any good water supply as yet it is no telling how deep they would have to go to get a proper vein of water, but the drillers think that they should not have to go down over a depth of ten or twenty feet further.

I beg to ask the Department to authorize the necessary expenditure in connection with the drilling of this well, the well pit roof had to be removed, and it will have to be replaced and some concrete replaced around the well casing.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

With reference to the well drilled for the combine teachers residence and hospital I beg to inform the Department that I am pleased to say that we have now secured a sufficient supply of water flow in the well, at a total depth from the surface of about 98 feet, this information was given to me on telephone this A.M and I am very pleased to know that the well has proved a success, as I was rather worried about it.

I will have Mr Wright agent for the Fairbanks-Morse Home water plant re install the water system, all he has to do is to put the pump in the well and connect it up to the first union connection in the well pit, every thing else is ready as it was installed Mr Wright will probably do this Monday May 19th.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 1st instant, No.66-2-8 with reference to the water supply system purchased from the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., Saint John, N.B. last October, for the combine teachers residence and hospital on the Tobique Reserve, and in the month of November the system was installed and put into operation, and it was discovered that the pump in a couple of strokes drained what water there was in the well, and the system could not be properly tried out as to its working capacity, so it had to be removed, and the well drilled a further depth to secure a sufficient flow of water, which is now being done and expect to finish in a few days.

I inclose herewith a writ of summons issued against me for the payment of the above mentioned water system, I had written the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., several times and explained the case to them, and they understood fully the circumstances regarding the well, and that the water system was purchased for the Department of Indian Affairs Ottawa.

I beg to submit herewith a voucher No. 291 amt. $596.52 in favor of the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., Saint John, N.B. for payment of their claim, without any cost, as you will note that they have made another bill of cost to the amount of $30.00 which I do not believe they have any right to, and I would ask the Department to take this matter up with them to that effect.

You will note that the contract guarantees their water system to give perfect satisfaction for one year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
The question of cost $25.00 referred to in this letter of the court fees etc. has been settled this morning with the local representative of the Canadian Fairbanks Co. and no action need be taken.

May 20, 1944

J. M. Smith

Sir,

In reply to your letter of August 30th, Ult. (No. 66-2-8) with accounts of Fewer Brothers enclosed for material and work done at the combine teachers residence and hospital at Tobique.

With regard to the account for the amount of $24.85 for connecting up the hot water tank to the kitchen stove, you will note in the specifications Page 45, Sec. 18, that it does not specify the connecting of the kitchen stove to the hot water tank and it was necessary to have this done in order to test out the hot water line, and I beg to submit herewith a voucher No.234 for this account.

With regard to the valves installed, I may say that it was necessary to have a valve arranged on each of the four main heating water lines immediately over the furnace boiler in case that the heat needed to be shut off from one part of the building and the other part required the heat, by the use of these valves the heat can be arranged to heat whatever part of the building that is required, and in case of a leak in one of the four lines, the line that has the leak can be shut off and the other three lines can be used to heat the building through the operation of these valves, and it was also considered that by installing these check valves that it would save fuel.

I beg to submit herewith the account for the four valves installed with certified voucher No.234 attached. Amt, $123.10

Your obedient servant,

In reply to your letter of the 3rd instant (No.66-2-8) with reference to the cost of labour installing cupboards in the trunk room of the teachers' residence, Tobique, I beg to inform the Department that Noel Francis, Indian, who was caretaker of the residence, had informed me that he could build the cupboards, but when he got started I found that he was not capable to do the work, and therefore would spoil the lumber that I had to build the cupboards with, so it was decided necessary to employ a carpenter that could do the work satisfactory, by making what was required by the Sisters for their cloths, etc., and to have the work done neatly.

Ottawa, April 23rd, 1925.

Sir:

Certain requests have been presented to the Department by Father Sylvester, of Tobique, who visited the Department today, on behalf of the Sisters in charge of the school and hospital on the Tobique Reserve. These may be enumerated briefly as follows:

1. To have small closets in bathrooms for brooms, dust pans, etc.
2. One bookcase for teachers' books.
3. In the laundry - to exchange an elbow for a "T" pipe with faucet.
4. To have an inexpensive partition (beaver board or wood) built, dividing the cellar into two rooms - one to be used for a domestic science workroom. In this case a wooden floor, a few inches above the cement base, would be sufficient to prevent the water floods in during the thawing season and heavy rains.
5. A table large enough to permit the cutting of garments, etc.
6. A cupboard for pieces of domestic science work, and material such as blankets, shoes, sweaters belonging to the Department.
7. To have a woodshed, a barn, a poultry house, etc., so we can keep a cow, hens, swine, which would be a great economy for the Hospital.
8. To enlarge the school house so the two classes can be in the same building.

With reference to the fitting up of a room in the basement of the residence and hospital building for domestic science work, I shall be pleased if you will give your opinion as to the necessity for having this done. The Department is anxious that the teachers conduct classes in domestic science for the older girls and women of the reserve; and if the cost in fitting up a room as suggested by the Sisters would not be too expensive, favourable consideration might be given to have the work done during the coming summer holidays. Please state what it would cost to have a beaver board partition and a wooden floor put in and the room fitted up and made serviceable for conducting classes. You should also state the expense in building any cupboards required and also a work table. When we have full information as to the cost involved and whether you would recommend that the work be done, consideration would then be given to carrying out the Reverend Sisters' request.

Please report on the need of items Nos. 1, 2 and 3, and give an estimate of the cost.

We have definitely informed Father Sylvester that there are no funds available to enlarge the school house during the present fiscal year and that it is hoped the Sisters can make other arrange-

C. J. Roberts, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Red Rapids, N.B.

This loss is divided into shell losses, primary copper loss, secondary copper loss, or core loss. It is quite difficult to figure the exact loss in each transformer on account of the different load.

Now we figure this loss on an average of 2%. That means that 2% of the capacity is lost. For instance, on your 6 K.W. transformer has a capacity of 5,000 watts. 2% of this is 100 or 100 watts lost every hour that the transformer is connected on the line. Now then, 100 watts every hour means...
2400 watts or 2.04 $18.00 lost in 24 hrs which at

loss goes in with the commercial lighting the

that goes on that line & you are charged with
the consumption from this meter which is
correct, the Co has about 15 transformers of
large capacity to stand the loss in, from which
amounts to a large sum in a year making
you understand the situation now. I am.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, relative to the requisition from the Rev. Sister Superior at Tobique for linoleum for the rooms in the teachers' residence and hospital, also for blankets, kitchen utensils, etc. I beg to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of these supplies, as mentioned in the list prepared by the Rev. Sister and which is returned herewith for your information. The total cost should not exceed the estimate of approximately $142. It would be advisable for you to consult the Rev. Sister, with a view to obtaining the supplies which will be satisfactory to her. If possible, you should obtain competitive prices and place the order with the firm quoting the lowest. After these supplies have been delivered, please forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. The enclosed list should be returned, attached to the accounts.

It is noted that you consider it will be satisfactory to have the vegetable garden ploughed in the spring, and you may arrange to have this work done at the same time as you are having any other ploughing carried out on the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 28th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing a voucher covering the cost of linoleum, blankets, crockery ware, etc., for the use of the teachers' residence on the Tobique Reserve. In this connection I have to inform you that a cheque in payment of this account has been sent.

It is noted, from the list of articles which you have not yet supplied, that the rubber tracking will cost approximately $24, also that the Sisters request an eight day clock, at a cost of approximately $12. The Department will approve of your incurring the above expenditure in the purchase of the rubber tracking and eight day clock. The other articles mentioned by you should be supplied as soon as possible.

Replying to your letters of the 21st instant, I beg to say that you may purchase the quantity of hard pine sheathing and quarter-round moulding required to make clothes closets for the teachers' residence, and you may also engage the labour in having these closets built.

You may also arrange for the purchase of two pieces of unbleached linen roller towelling, about 18" wide, and 1 dozen dessert dishes and bread and butter plates in white and gold porcelain.

Please keep all expenses in the purchase of the above authorized supplies as low as possible. When the purchase has been made, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost, also for the labour in the building of the clothes closets.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

In connection with this list of supplies, it is thought that some are for residence purposes while others are for the use of the hospital. I am, therefore, returning your letter, and have to request that you will state opposite each item the service for which it is required or have a separate list prepared showing the articles required for the teachers' use and for the use of the hospital. I may say that our funds this year are limited, and it is necessary to keep all expenditure for school purposes as low as possible.

When we have full information as asked for, consideration will then be given to authorizing you to make the purchase. Please return the enclosed communication with your reply.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

The question has arisen as to what primary allotment in this year's Appropriation should be used for a water tank at the Tobique hospital and teachers' residence - a combined building. I believe it is now timely for the Medical portion of the Vote to undertake somewhat more of the expenditure than in the past.

Upon reviewing the costs at this school, I find that for the five years ended March 31, 1927, the average yearly expenditure for all purposes for the two-classroom Indian day school was $991.00. During the fiscal years 1923-24 and 1924-25 the hospital and teachers' residence was erected at a cost to Indian Education of $22,670. I believe at this time some of the furnishing, which was additional, was charged to the Medical portion of the New Brunswick Vote. This charge on Indian Education was at least $18,000 more than if we had built a teachers' residence only.

With reference to the current expenses since that time, I believe that they have averaged $3,464 for the past six years. This was at least $1,300 more per year than if a day school only was being operated. Half of this extra expense, of course, is the salary of the third teacher. One of the Sisters is so classified, but, as a matter of fact, her duties are those of nurse and field matron.

I propose to discuss this with Dr. Stone, with a view to a more fair apportioning of the costs in future. In view of the difficulties of changing the classification of the third worker, I suggest that $600 or $700 of the miscellaneous expenses be paid from Medical primary allotment.
Perth, N.B., May 23rd, 1932.

Sir,

I am obliged to report that storage tank of Tobique Reserve Hospital has rusted through at one end and is beyond repair. The rusting or corrosion came from the inside and was caused by the hard well water. I had this tank welded three times last week and Mr Armstrong tells me it is useless to try and patch it.

The present tank is 700 gal. capacity, I believe 500 gal would be sufficient.

Would the Department authorize purchase of or supply direct a tank of this capacity, it should have over three feet in diameter anything wider would not go through door-way leading to basement, the length does not matter.

March 19, 1934.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Some years ago, the Department erected a new school building on the Tobique Reserve (No. 20). The cost of this building was paid wholly from the Appropriation for Indian Education, and, in addition, any repairs made since the building was erected have been paid from the same source.

Part of the building has always been devoted to hospital purposes. Three Reverend Sisters are employed, one of whom devotes all her time to the work of the hospital. Her salary has also been paid from the Appropriation for Indian Education.

I have discussed this matter with Dr. Stone, and I would appreciate your concurrence in the following:

1. From April 1, 1934, any disbursements in connection with the repairs or upkeep of the part of the building devoted to hospital purposes should be paid from Medical Vote.

2. The salary of the Rev. Sister engaged in hospital work should be provided in the Medical Vote for the fiscal year 1935-36 (from April 1, 1935). I understand that there is no provision for her in the Medical Vote for 1934-35, and we have provided for her salary during that fiscal year.

Approved by

Dr. McGill.

Perth, N. B. May 1st. 1935.

Sir,

As the Department is aware there is a tubercular patient, namely Fred Nash now in Tobique Hospital. This boy is in a very weak condition and I do not believe it will be possible to carry out our original plan of placing him in a small cabin and arranging for his meals through some Indian family.

Sister Electa has suggested the following plan to take care of this and any subsequent cases.

That the roof of the verandah on the right side of Teachers Residence be raised to the level of the main roof making an upstairs verandah or sleeping porch for use of the Sisters. This would leave the present porch for the use of the patients, which could be partially enclosed.

I would estimate the cost in the vicinity of $60.00 which would be little more than cost of building and equipping a small cabin for our present patient and would be permanent.

Trusting this expenditure meets with the Department's approval, I am,

Your obedient servant,

N. H. MacPhail, Indian Agent.

Ottawa, April 22, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of labour return for $25.00 which you forwarded in connection with work done by Wm. Ennis. You state in your letter that the medical officer considers that George Bernard should be assisted. You should have reported this matter to the Department at once, as it is not possible, owing to present regulations, to pay from the relief appropriation the amount of $25.00 which you state Wm. Ennis earned. This amount will have to be paid from the Appropriation for Indian Education, and it is likely that the Auditor General will take exception to the payment, as we are also paying Bernard at the rate of $200 a year for the same service. The account of Andover & Perth Farmers Co-operative Company, Ltd., is being paid at $293.00.

Please let me have a full statement regarding Ennis' employment and why you approved of this without first receiving our authority. It is going to be extremely difficult to straighten out the matter, and all the trouble could have been avoided if we had been informed before any action was taken.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

N. H. MacPhail, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Perth, N.B.
Perth, N.B., Apr. 25th, 1936.

Sir,

In reply to letter #66-2-8 dated Apr. 22nd, re Wm. Ennis.

When I was asked if Bernard could have a man to assist him for a few days during the cold weather and I asked Ennis to help him I thought his relief would cover it, which is the reason it was not reported. Bernard's condition did not improve and Ennis was kept on.

I have been under the impression that an Indian could be asked to work one or two days a week in payment of relief orders he might be receiving. Ennis receives $2.50 per week.

If this expenditure does not meet with the approval of the Department and has to be deducted from Bernard's salary I think the amount should be only $18.00.

Bernard on the other hand does all sort of work outside of his official duties for which he receives no pay, and I thought it only fair that he have some assistance when he required it.

I regret not reporting this matter and trust it can be settled.

Your obedient servant,

N.H. MacPhail, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir:-

With reference to your letter of the 5th inst., regarding expense incurred by James Deveau and Chief Saulis last August when investigating an alleged timber trespass, the Department is not prepared to allow this item of $7.28 for the reason that you did not sanction the trip made by the Chief.

Matters relating to administration of a reserve must be dealt with by the agent and not by the Indian Chief, and in this instance the Chief should have notified you of the alleged report, and if for some reason or another you were unable to attend to the matter yourself, and delegated the Chief to make an investigation, the account for expense would be in order.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR RYAN regarding his inspection of the Tobique Indian Day School.

Date of Inspection—October 7, 1937.

"Reverend Mother Electa is certainly a great leader and under her care the Indians receive a good training. The Department should encourage her to carry on this splendid work.

She complained to me while there of the sad need of an electric washer and ironer. They have so much washing to do.

November 8, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Reverend Father Ryan has appealed to the Department on behalf of the Tobique Hospital to provide the institution with an electric washer, ironer and refrigerator. There has been previous correspondence on these matters which there is no need to repeat.

It seems well to inquire how the present arrangement is working as regards hospital patients and the cost of their care. The plan is not so old that it cannot be regarded as experimental. The Department's view in most enterprises of this kind is that it should not be asked to pay more than the services cost and that the missionary institution should not be asked to carry on work at a loss. I need not recount the complicated nature of the institution at Tobique in its different functions as teachers' residence and hospital.

There have been some new developments about Government property and the Department's impression is that the present arrangement should be recast in such a manner that the Department would supply, own and keep up all permanent equipment, including bedding and linen, and pay to the Sisters such a rate as would cover food and laundry for the patients but no other service except the compensation for the services of Sister Electa which would be continued at its present rate. To open the discussion

N. H. MacPhail, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Perth, N. B.
the Department is prepared to consider the installation of a refrigerator but not of a washer or ironer for reasons given in a previous letter. It is suggested that a rate of $1.00 per day would cover feeding and laundry but this figure is to be regarded as a suggestion only and subject to further discussion on either side. I think you must be asked to get as careful figures as you can on the actual cost of these services and that the Sisters must be asked to make them available to you.

On reviewing the hospital accounts it is observed that Mrs. John Deveau, with active pulmonary tuberculosis, has been in the hospital since May 3. The Department is prepared to remove this patient to any sanatorium in New Brunswick and to pay for her maintenance there, preferring that the space be occupied by a more active and less communicable type of patient. It thinks also that the case of Mrs. Lockwood should be reviewed as she has been in the hospital since August 25 with a diagnosis of chronic bronchitis. In these proposals it is not the Department's wish necessarily to reduce the revenue of the Sisters but it is obvious that a hospital of this size is not a suitable place for active tuberculosis or indeed for any very long term patient.

Dear Mr. MacPhail:

As requested by Mr. McInnes in his letter of recent date, you will find attached detailed account of all expenses paid out in this institution (Teachers residence and Hospital) from January 1st to October 31st 1937.

After preparing this report I sent a copy of it to our Mother General in Saint John - along with a copy of the correspondence you received from the Department. It would have been returned to me at once but our Mother General was away on a visiting tour of our institutions in Western Canada and only returned November 29th.

She agrees with me that the $2. per day per patient is very satisfactory but that $1.00 per day would not be sufficient. We are glad of an opportunity to furnish the Department with a detailed statement of actual expenses paid. Without these long term cases that have been in the hospital during the past year our hospital cheque would rarely exceed $25.00, and, as you know, provision could not be made outside the hospital for the very sick patients that we have cared for here. Take for instance the case of Mrs. Lockwood, you were paying $4.00 per week for a woman to care for her, in addition to her relief clothing, wood, etc. We were obtaining her help every other week. She really should have been in the hospital a month earlier or have someone during the day and another at night during her last month at home as she was very sick and we only admitted her when the doctor said she needed hospital care, as she would die in a short time, which really happened. In regard to Mrs. John DeVeu as you know we did not wish to admit her here but the doctor asked us to admit her as she had a family of little children. Her condition now is very poor. The doctor is expecting her to die at any time. It is now too late to remove her to a Sanitarium. We will be very pleased to co-operate with the Department is keeping out of the hospital as long as possible such long term cases.

Our Mother General wishes me to say that the Community appreciates the fact that our dealings with the Department have been extremely satisfactory and that she is pleased that we will have a Frigidaire for our hospital and that, regarding the electric washer, she will be very willing to refund to us the price of the washer so that we will not have to do without this necessary equipment.

I am sorry that there has been so much delay in following up the correspondence and I trust that the information attached will be of service.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Ref. your letter April 13 - Electric Refrigerator Tobique Hospital.

You will recall previous correspondence on this matter and a financial statement you sent forward on December 7, 1937. That statement went far to convince the Department that a new arrangement is required, but it was thought better to wait until the beginning of the new fiscal year before it should be further discussed. If you have a copy, you will see that the Reverend Sisters have charged into their operating expenses $1,1147.00, much of which represents expenditure for their own clothing, travelling expenses, dentist, insurance, chapel expense and so forth, none of which are charges which have much to do with the operation of the hospital, or indeed, of the teacher's residence, they being personal living costs of the sisters themselves.

In fact, this sum, with the credit balance on nine month's operations, is almost equal to the cost which might properly be assigned to the hospital operation. This seems to indicate to the Department that the daily rate for maintenance of patients should be reduced from $2.00 to about $1.00 or a little more. If this were agreed upon, there would be nothing to stand in the way of the Department purchasing the electric refrigerator out of the saving.

Memorandum:

- Director -

The following is a brief report of my short visit, November 6, P.M., to the New Brunswick North Agency.

TORIQUE RESERVE

SCHOOL

The school is a two-roomed building in very good condition. Repairs are required to the roof over the entrance, and the stone foundation at the east or back end will have to be torn down and rebuilt. This work should be done next year. The children are in a clean, neat, healthy condition. Attendance at the time of my visit was very good. However, during the month of September, and part of October, many children went to Maine to pick potatoes. Teacher Smith condemned this practice very strongly. As stated in my other reports the annual movement of children to Maine should be discouraged. The school is equipped with electricity which is supplied by a local Power Company.

TEACHERS' RESIDENCE AND NURSING STATION

This is an excellent building and it is kept in an immaculate condition. It is my opinion that this building should be made available as a hospital to take care of the needs of all the Indians in the St. John River Valley. At little cost it could be renovated to accommodate fifteen to eighteen beds. A complete laundry service would necessarily have to be installed consisting of washing machines, ironers, etc., - in addition a root-house would have to be constructed adjoining the basement, to provide storage for vegetables, canned fruits, etc. There is a very urgent need to provide hospital space to accommodate the number of sick Indians in the Maritimes. There are many T.B. cases that are not receiving the proper medical care because it is impossible to obtain space in the white hospitals. By converting this building into a hospital it would provide immediate space, and would make it possible for the Medical Division to do something really worth while to take care of medical cases.

This building is already equipped with electricity from a local Power Company.

If this recommendation is approved then a residence will have to be constructed to house the teachers and the nursing sisters.

J. E. Morris,
Welfare Division.

Dear Sir:

Certain changes are necessary in the laundry room, Tobique Teachers' Residence. At the present time the source of hot water is a range boiler connected to the kitchen range.

I would recommend that an oil burning heater be installed in the basement, doing away with the range boiler in the kitchen. This would provide a constant supply of hot water and eliminate a fire in the kitchen range a great part of the time during the summer months.

There is a small stove in the laundry room, upon which an ordinary wash boiler is used to sterilize patients' bedding. This stove is worn out and must be replaced. I would recommend that a stove similar to that now in use be purchased, as the new heater will not eliminate the necessity for a stove.

The oil heater installed will cost approximately $200. As yet I have not prices on the new stove but I would estimate the cost from $50 to $75.

Report of the School on the Woodstock Reserve for the month of May 1911.

Remarks: One holiday May 24th.

Empire Day was duly observed by patriotic lessons singing and drawing. Lessons on Empire, history of the flag and saluting the flag. Also the drawing of St. Patrick's, St. George's, St. Andrew's and Union Jack.

Pupils enjoy the Games which are taken in the open air (weather permitting).

Calisthenics are taught and have been since the school was started.

Hygiene, from the Ontario Prescribed Text Book, has not been taught, but will be from this time on. Advanced scholars had been studying Health Readers I & II N.B. Series while instructions on Health and Cleanliness etc., had been given to the younger pupils.

Majority do very good work in sewing.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Miss Mary L. Cogger, teacher of the Woodstock Indian Day School, applies for an increase in her salary. Miss Cogger is a new teacher and began duties upon the re-opening of the school after the last summer holidays with salary at the rate of $400.00 per annum. She has an enrolment of 15 pupils with an average attendance of 10.

Mr. Inspector Ryan in a recent report of inspection states that he would like to see better salaries paid to the teachers in the Indian day schools in New Brunswick and that these teachers should receive $100.00 more than the average paid to white schools.

In New Brunswick there are 11 day schools the teachers of which are paid as follows:- four at $400.00; four at $450.00 and three at $500.00.

The Inspector reports that Miss Cogger has been meeting with fair success and, as she had only been a brief period in the school, he could not judge as to what success she would make. There is no doubt that the salary she now receives is very low. She has to pay $7.00 a week for board and that leaves her very little for other expenses. She has received the bonus from the date she began duties.

I would recommend that she be allowed an increase of $100.00.

WOODSTOCK INDIAN DAY SCHOOL CLOSING

The closing exercises at the Woodstock Indian Day School, located at the Indian Reservation, took place on Tuesday morning, June 30th. A number of those interested came down from Woodstock by car, while some of the ladies in the neighborhood witnessed the program, which follows:

"Holy God We Praise Thy Name"—Chorus, by School.

Welcome Address.—A little girl.

"We're Pretty Little Birdies"—Song and Exercise by five little girls.

"Who's in the Bird's Nest?"—Dialogue by eight children.

"The Stolen Bird's Nest"—Recitation.

"Three, Bird Song by five little girls, chorus by School.

"Don't tell about the Bird's Nest in the Daisies!"—Recitation.

"Pretty Little Raindrops Laughing kissed the Daisies"—Song by school.

"Rapid Jack"—Recitation.

"Be Kind"—Song by School.

"Flag Exercise and Wand Drill"—By School.

The pupils gave an exhibition of Wand Drill movements, keeping time to their own singing of "Fling out the Flag," "The Three little Sisters" and "only a small Bit of Bunting."

The Wards were formed by joined Flag Staffs.

Flag Salute—School.

God Save the King—School.

Good-bye little School-room—School.

Hon. J. L. Carleton and John P. Malaney spoke briefly congratulating the young scholars on their rapid advancement in the English language, and referred in very laudatory terms of the evidence of strenuous work on the part of Sister Agnetis, as was evident in the program of the day, and by Sister Michael, in charge of the hygiene work at the Indian Reservation.

His Worship Mayor Belson made a hit at the start by making some remarks in the Indian language, which the children affirmed were correct, and he said that there were only 500 words in the Indian language. He suggested that Sister Agnetis prepare a vocabulary with the assistance of the older Indians, during the coming term, which she promised to do. He complimented the Sisters on the program presented, and was greatly pleased with the natural voices of the children. He was much impressed with the deportment and respect shown by the children. This was probably caused by the love of the children for their teachers—it takes love to make flowers thrive. It was only stated that the children should get a reasonable and fair cultivation in the English language. When he was a lad, working in his father's store in Woodstock, he learned a part of the Indian dialect. Those from the present Indian reservation, used to make baskets, ax handles, brooms, etc., and sell these articles in the town, but now these are manufactured by a large scale, and the Indians have lost that sort of employment. He congratulated the Sisters on the care they are taking of the native children, and assured them that they would find for their work they would receive a cherished star in their crowns in the years to come.

The children then enjoyed a treat of ice cream, cake, sandwiches, candy which was supplied and served by Mrs. E. J. McManus and Mrs. R. C. Tait.

The visitors then examined the work done in the Manual and Science Departments, and were surprised to find such neat and beautiful work in sewing and knitting done by such small children.

The children looked very neat and attractive. The girls wore a blue and white striped uniform and the boys a dark grey. These uniforms were a part of the regular school uniform. Two other khaki uniforms were also made and worn by the children during the school year.

The Sisters in speaking of their past year's work with the Indian children referred especially to the respect, obedience and docility of the children. They tried so hard to do the little things that were asked of them.

The attendance of the children for the year as read out was most extraordinary. During four months of the year 100 per cent was made, and not a single case of truancy was reported during the year.

The progress during the year was most satisfactory.

The decorations on the board were not only decorative, but served as incentives and aids in helping the children in their work.
St. Gertrude's Convent,
Woodstock, N.B.

Dear Mr. Scott, Dept. Supt. Genl.,
Of Ind. Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Last June, I had the pleasure of interviewing you and Hon. Mr. Stewart, Minst. of the Interior, re. better transportation facilities for the Rev. sisters from their Convent at Woodstock to the Ind. day school, a distance of three miles. I pointed out that the Rev. sisters were daily forced to take a cold dinner in the school on the Reserve, not having time to drive to their Convent by team and return to open school at the appointed time. This often breaks down their health, for their custom is to make the mid-morning meal their chief repast, so they retire so early after supper that a heavy meal at that hour would likewise have drastic results on their health.

Quick transportation would overcome all difficulties, allowing the sisters to be home for a good hot dinner. For this reason, I suggested to you and the Hon. Minister that an extra $100.00 be given to each of the two sisters for a period of five or six years, this two hundred to go yearly to pay for a Ford closed car. Father Leckery said he would at once purchase the car, if he had a guarantee that in five or six years he would be reimbursed. I was given to understand by both in this interview, that such was agreeable to you and that it would be carried out. In the meantime, the Rev. sisters have certainly passed through another trying year, bearing patiently their trials, yet not without signs that bespeak of failing health. I trust the Dept. will act in this matter at once.

Yours respectfully,

Rev. sister Agnes is very weak; she has been confined to her bed for over a year. You will remember she fell exhausted in the Woodstock Ind. school. On the following day she was taken on a cot to St. John's Infirmary, where she still lies, being but a few days removed from eternity. She claims that her cold dinners were much the cause of her breakdown.

I have to inform you that Rev. P. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of New Brunswick, has nominated the services of Sister M. Victorine as teacher of the Woodstock Indian Day School, to succeed Sister M. Mercia. The Department is approving of the appointment of Sister Victorine, with salary at the rate of $80 per teaching month, less 10 percent during the current fiscal year.

I would request that you give Sister Victorine any assistance you can in her work at this school and in encouraging a regular attendance of the Indian children.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

B. J. Griffiths, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N.B.
Dear Reverend Father,

I am writing to tell you that little Victorie had to have an operation for appendicitis last Monday. She is now at the Hamilton Hospital making a good recovery. But of course will have to be out of school for the rest of November and December. I hope she shall be able to start again in January.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have to inform you that arrangements have been completed for the taking over by the Sisters of Charity of the work in connection with the Woodstock Indian Day School from September 1, 1924, the beginning of the next school year. Ottawa, December 23, 1924.

ENCLOSURE

Madam:

Your letter of the 28th ultimo addressed to Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools has been forwarded to this Department.

In reply, I beg to say that the salaries of teachers in the Indian Day Schools are paid on a basis of ten teaching months in the school year. The School year begins on September 1st and ends on the following June 30th. You are requested to forward through the office of your Local Agent a return showing the names of the pupils, days taught, etc., at the end of September, December, March and June. For September, as there is only one teaching month in that quarter, you were paid 1/10 of your average salary and at the end of each of the other three quarters, you will be paid 3/10 of your annual salary. You will, therefore, see that when payments are made at the end of June next, you will have received your full salary for the teaching year.

The amount due for the quarter ending December 31st, 1924, is 3/10 of $500.00 or $150.00. From this amount, the Department is deducting the advance of $75.00, leaving a balance due of $75.00. The same amount is due Sister Michael for the quarter ending December 31st, and cheques for these amounts are being forwarded under separate cover.

During the present fiscal year, bonus is allowed to Teachers of Indian Schools at the rate of $15.00 a month, for each teaching month. There is therefore due you for the December quarter $45.00 bonus and the same amount is due Sister Michael.

Cheques for these amounts are enclosed herewith.

You should prepare at once and forward to Mr. Agent Griffith on the form provided for that purpose, a return showing the names of the pupils, days taught, etc., during the December quarter.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sr. Mary Agnetis,
Woodstock,

We warrant this Seat not to warp or split for a period of five years, and will replace any Seat that does warp or split under ordinary service within that period.

Ideal Construction

The fact that the Seats are homogeneous and will not warp or split, makes them indestructible and perfect in point of sanitation. The Tanks, being moulded solid without joints or metal lining, are ideal in construction. There is nothing about them to corrode or deteriorate in any way.
Perfect and Durable Finish
and Grain

We have devised special machinery which produces a perfect match to natural wood both in grain and color. We use the very best varnish and by special treatment secure a high lustre that is very durable.

Furnished Complete

J-M Sanitor Seats and Tanks are furnished complete with our regular fittings and attachments. We have adopted as standard fittings, those which have proven most satisfactory to the trade at large and which we can safely recommend.

In the top supply High Tanks and Low Tanks, we furnish a direct action ball cock guaranteed to stand any pressure up to and including 150 lbs. We have adopted this as a standard because of its positive action, simplicity and ease of installation. Where required we will also furnish compound lever ball cocks at a slight additional cost. Bottom supply High Tanks are furnished with compound lever ball cocks as standard.

Economical

Our large manufacturing facilities enable us to offer this line of goods at attractive prices, no higher than other high grade Seats and Tanks on the market.

Sanitor Seats and Tanks are the most economical fixtures. The cost of maintenance is practically nothing. In this point alone, they save the difference in their cost over cheap fixtures in a year or two.

Sir:

In a requisition dated the 16th instant, the teacher of the Woodstock Indian Day School requests authority to purchase milk. In this connection I beg to say that you may supply the following quantities of milk to the schools in your Agency:

Woodstock - 5 Qts. daily,
Kingsclear - 6-8 Qts. daily,
St. Mary's - 5 Qts. daily,
Oromocto - 6-8 Qts. daily.

It is presumed that you can secure this at a cost not exceeding that paid last year, viz., 8 cents a quart.

The milk should only be served from November 1, 1934, to March 31, 1935.

The teacher of each school should keep an accurate account of the quantity of milk supplied each day. This information should be given to you at the end of each month, in order that you can prepare the usual voucher, in triplicate. A separate account should be forwarded covering the cost of the milk supplied each school, and the date and file number of this letter should be quoted as authority for the purchase.

The teachers should see that the milk is received in clean containers and that it is kept in a sanitary condition, also that the full quantity received is used by the pupils every day, without waste.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for the province of New Brunswick, in a report on his inspection of the Woodstock Indian Day School, on the 4th instant, recommends that repairs be made to the roof of the school building. He states that this roof leaks. He recommends, also, that the cracks in the plaster on the inside of the school building be filled and that, during the summer holidays, the floor be well scrubbed and, when dry, given a coat of hot oil. He recommends, further, that the out-houses be thoroughly cleaned, white-washed and placed in a good, sanitary condition.

I would request that you inform the Department regarding the repairs required to the roof and the plaster, giving an estimate of the cost and stating how you would recommend having the work done. During the holidays, you should arrange to have the out-houses repaired, cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition. All expense for this purpose should be kept as low as possible.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge Department's letter of June 20th referring to repairs required on the Woodstock Indian School.

Six bunches of shingles will be required to repair the roof of the school. The plank walk from the outhouse to the school must be repaired, as some of the planks are rotted and broken. Reverend F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for the province of New Brunswick, in reporting on his recent inspection of the Woodstock Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the work which was carried out last summer, in repairing the plaster in the classroom. He states that the walls require to be painted or tinted, as the white material which was used in filling up the cracks last summer should be coloured, to match the paint on the walls, and that the interior of the building would be greatly improved if the walls were repainted. Dear Sir-

I beg to acknowledge the Department letter of Oct. 17th File no. 56-5-5 in regard to repairs made to Indian Day School at Woodstock.

I am at a loss to know why Reverend Father Ryan should say the roof was patched where it did not leak, and that it now leaks worse than ever, Sister Katharine informs me the roof does not leak at all.

I realize there will have to be a new roof on this building next year, but on the advice of a competent carpenter, I was assured a few patches would stop the leaks and save, for awhile at least an expenditure of nearly $300.00

As for the cracks which were fixed in the walls of the class room they do show white and of course would look much better painted. If the Department will recall I had less than one month to complete repairs to four schools. Woodstock was the last one repaired and time would not permit me to paint the interior.

I would say the approximate cost of this would be at
the least seventy-five dollars including labor.

I will immediately carry out instructions contained in your letter, regarding the roof.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Reverend Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, in a report on his recent inspection of the Woodstock Indian Day School, recommends that the interior woodwork, walls, ceiling, etc., be well washed and cleaned and that some minor repairs be made to the steps at the entrance. He also states that the out-houses should be well cleaned and whitewashed, inside and outside, and some minor repairs made.

I would request that you will arrange to have the above mentioned work carried out during the present summer holidays. The floor of the school should be thoroughly washed, allowed to dry for some days and then given a coat of hot oil. The out-houses should be cleaned and repaired, as requested. Please have any necessary repairs made to the steps at the entrance to the school.

You should keep all costs in this connection as low as possible and forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

The fence of the Indian School yard, Woodstock N. B., has been in bad condition for sometime. Now a part of it—that between the highway and the school is to be moved over toward the school building a space of some feet, to enable the Department of Public Works, Province of New Brunswick, to lay hard surface road. The wires are not in fit condition to be used again. It will be necessary to get new material for this fence.

The road workers are ready to put it up for us if material is supplied, and it is certainly necessary to have a fence for the school yard. The old posts that are between the school yard and the highway have been replaced with new ones by the Provincial Government.

May I have authority to purchase wire fencing from the firm of Steward and Steward, Woodstock for this purpose. Approximate cost, $35.

Dear Sir,-

It seems impossible to keep the basement in the Woodstock Indian Day School dry. The drainage is inadequate. For instance, today there was about two inches of water on the floor. Sister Katherine is forced to wear rubbers and sweep the water over to the drain before the children can go downstairs for their domestic work. Eventually, I believe it will be necessary to dig approximately 200 feet and put in a tile drain system. It may be that when the water runs off the roof, it will not drain away but just remains at the base of the wall and seeps down through.

I believe this could be overcome to a great extent, if we had a banking put around the school and this covered with gravel. It would take care of much of the water, which I am sure runs in around the stems and down into the basement. This could be done without a great deal of expense. I will need 4 or 5 loads of gravel and possibly a load of dirt. I would employ an Indian to do the banking.

Today I had a competent engineer inspect the basement with me and this is what he suggests for the time being, of course if this will not take care of the water, in the spring it will be necessary to put in a tiling system.

Dear Mr. MacCutchon,

On account of the lack of light I am finding it very difficult to dispense medicines in the little basement room of our school which is the only available place for this purpose. The small windows admit very little light at any time and on dark cloudy days it is almost impossible to read the labels and do the dispensing. So I humbly request to have electric light installed. This would also be a benefit to the schoolroom as the boards are difficult to be seen by the children on dark days. But the principal need is in the basement where are located the...
I also petition that the Domestic Science kitchen and the Dispensary be separated by a partition. At present they are not and the medicines and poisons such as syrup, iodine etc. are all in the room where the children go for lunch and for cooking lessons etc., and there is danger of breakage and even serious accidents might happen as I can not always be present when they go there.

A small partition would separate the dispensary from the kitchen. A door would be needed and in the dispensary shelves for the drugs and bottles etc. Now I am using old packing boxes which are very inadequate.

I trust that you will be so kind as to take up this matter with the Indian Department as
I can assure you that both these items are badly needed.

Thanking you for the kind interest shown towards our work in the past I remain

Yours very sincerely,

Sister M. Katherine

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,-

It seems impossible to keep the water from running into the basement of the Indian Day School, Woodstock. Almost at any time of the year the children have to wear rubber and in fact, Sister Katharine wears rubber boots most of the time.

I dread to think of the basement this spring with so much snow and water. I was really at a loss trying to figure some way that it could be drained. Several engineers have looked this over and they all are of the same opinion, and that is, the present drain is practically useless.

In order to eliminate this, which Sister Katherine tells me is getting worse all the time, one would have to go back of the school closets 50 feet, dig a trench down to the hard pan in the direction indicated on the enclosed sketch and put in either a 6" tile drain (smaller would not take maximum flow of water) or a rock drain 4" square to lead down over the hill into the brook back of the house occupied by Mrs. Doc Polchies. This would probably isolate the school from the underground water supply that floods it. (I am told that the school was built in a swamp.) To do this work, labour would probably cost from $200.00 to $250.00.

A rock drain would entail practically all wages, a tile drain about $35.00 to $40.00 for the tile, but I think it would make a job.
A direct drain into the road ditch would not be allowed by the powers that be at present. We must do something or we will spend much more than this in doctor bills and at times it is impossible to get down in the basement for the Domestic Science classes or dispenser of medicines.

As I said before I have consulted engineers about this and I am told by men, who surely should know, that this is the only way to eliminate this underground flow of water, which floods the school basement.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

Enclosure.

R. Lee MacGutchon.

Please return enclosed sketch.
Ottawa,
April 13, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant in which you recommend digging a drain at the Woodstock Indian day school.

It was only found possible to provide in our current year's appropriation an amount of $300.00 for repairs and improvements at the schools in your Agency. You will, therefore, note that the drain at the Woodstock school will involve the expenditure of practically the whole amount available.

However, as the work appears necessary you may proceed with it as soon as weather conditions permit and a tile drain should be provided.

It is understood, of course, that only Indians will be employed and in engaging them you should hire all able-bodied Indians who are at present on relief. As soon as they start work no further relief should be allowed to them. Any able-bodied Indian who refuses work in digging the drain should be cut off relief.

Please let me know when you require an accountable cheque for this work.

Yours truly,

R. Lee MacCutcheon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.

Dear Sir,-

I am in receipt of your letter of April 13, File No. 56-5-5 re-digging a drain at the Woodstock Indian School.

I believe it will be the first of June before I will be able to do this work. The ground here is covered with snow and there is still 4 or 5 feet of ice in the St. John River.

I note that the amount of $300.00 was provided for the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements for the schools in my Agency, and that it will involve practically the whole amount available for the work at Woodstock. I had hoped to paint the interior of the St. Mary's Indian School. I do not know when it was painted last, but it most certainly needs paint. The old paint is practically all off the Woodwork, and the walls and ceilings need doing as well. The Woodstock School requires paint on the outside in the worst way, and for that matter, Kingsclear School also needs paint on the outside, but as this school is down in the reserve and not visible from the highway, we could pass that up for another year, but if it is at all possible to secure funds, I would paint the interior of the St. Mary's School and the exterior of the Woodstock School.
Please let me have your opinion on this as it will save unnecessary correspondence later on in securing authority for this work. Believe me, Sir, the paint job recommended herein is necessary.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent
R. Lee MacGutcheon.

Dear Sir:

There are so many demands that it is practically impossible for the Department to exceed the amount actually appropriated. Under these circumstances I cannot hold out any hope that funds will be available for the painting at the Kingsclear and St. Mary's schools. Dear Sir:

I beg to submit report of Indian Agency N.B. Southwestern for the month of May 1939.

WOODSTOCK RESERVE

This reserve was visited four times during the month. All unemployment relief was discontinued May 1st. Monday, May 15th, I started excavation for the French drain, using Indian labour with a white foreman. I am attaching a rough sketch of the work as it is completed. I am delighted with the results. The Indians worked well and the foreman understood his job. Two competent Provincial Government engineers have inspected the drain and assure me that now we have a job that will last indefinitely. The school basement is dry, the spring is dry. Fortunately I was able to procure the rock without cost, which effected a considerable saving.

R. Lee MacCutcheon,

Woodstock Reserve

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the Department's decision not to allow any grant for the purchase of Christmas prizes.

It is considered that the teacher should be able to arrange a concert a week or so before Christmas and either charge a small admission fee or take up a collection. By so doing sufficient funds should be raised to provide a Christmas treat for the pupils attending the school. In addition it should have a tendency to make the Indian parents realize that they have some obligations with regard to the education of their children.

Dear Sir:

Woodstock Indian Day School.

The population of the Woodstock Indian Reserve has increased so rapidly that the school house at the present time is not large enough to accommodate the children of school age on the reserve. There are, at the present time, 24 names appearing on the register, and this number fill the seats to capacity.

There are 10 new pupils of school age to go the coming term, while there is only one old enough to leave, therefore 9 new seats are required before the opening of school on October 1, 1943.

This is not the biggest trouble however, as the school is too small, and in order to place the extra number of desks something will have to be done to the school room.

At the present time, the sewing room might be used but even then the pupils would be crowded, and with the ever increasing population, it would only supply room enough for a year or so.

I would like for Mr. Arneil to discuss this situation with the proper authorities before leaving Ottawa, in order that we might know what to do when he arrives.

Your obedient Servant,

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
May 28, 1942.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

I wish to refer to your letter of July 26, regarding the painting of the Woodstock Indian School.

I found it impossible to get anyone to paint this school, although I had one painter who promised to do it and then disappointed me.

At last, Tom Nash, the man who painted the St. Marys school, agreed to go to Woodstock with me and to give the walls and ceiling one coat of paint. This he did with the help of a man, Ed Gallagher, for five hours.

The interior of this school should have another coat and the entry and subbase should be painted as well. We have nearly enough paint to do this and Mr. Nash would go up again if authorized to do so.

The labour and material for painting the Woodstock and St. Marys schools were kept pretty well within the amount allowed although the Woodstock school received less labour and material than that of St. Marys.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

R.A. Hoey,

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,

Re: Woodstock Indian School.

The steps and floor of the porch covering the entrance of this school will have to be replaced, together with the frame work which holds the floor.

A new cement platform will have to be put around the pump at the well. I would especially recommend that this be cement, as the winter ice is very hard on a wooden one.

The plank walk from the school to the outhouses is decayed and will also have to be replaced.

The cost of the above repairs will be in the vicinity of £65.00.

May I have authority to have this work done during the summer holidays?

Edward J. Whalen,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re Voucher No. 461.

The Sisters of the Woodstock Indian School had found the building, especially the Domestic Science Room, very dark during cloudy days and had asked for electric lights.

When Dr McGill visited the school on October 19, 1944, the matter was taken up with him and he gave permission to have the electric lights installed.

Steve Pike, an electrician, and I believe the only one who is doing that kind of work in Woodstock, agreed to install 6 lights, put in 2 switches and do the rest of the work, the same as shown on bills covered by the above numbered voucher, less bulbs, for $75.00.

John Whalen, who does not make a living at that kind of work, said he would do the wiring, supply an extra light and switch and all the bulbs for $70.00. Therefore I gave the work to him.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
This should be shown in detail. Did he buy the material? Cost? And wages?
Ottawa, February 14, 1945.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Acting Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.

The Department finds it necessary to return your voucher No. 461. If the statement attached to the voucher is signed by Mr. Whalen we can consider the contract and arrange payment without being supplied with all the details.

I am rather surprised that Dr. McGill gave instructions for this work, as it was not his usual custom to give verbal authority for expenditure. Besides, it has not been our usual practice for some years to install electric lights in Indian day schools. However, as stated above, we are prepared to pay the account, provided the matter is handled in the manner suggested.

Encl.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Woodstock NB

Dear Mr. Whalen,

Is it possible to have something done at once regarding the Woodstock Indian School?

The seating capacity of the classroom is about twenty seats. At present there are thirty-four seats in the front row within a few inches of the teacher's desk, making it impossible to carry on any drill or activity work. There are thirty-six pupils attending school; seven are in Grade VII. Of these, three will have attained their sixteenth birthday in 1946. The following grade is Grade VI.

During the next three years there will be an average of six pupils per year.

Under these conditions it is evident that immediate measures must be taken.

Sincerely yours,

Sister M. Dobroza (teacher).
Fredericton, N.B.
July 9, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Woodstock Indian School.

Enclosed you will find a letter which I received from Sister Dolorosa, teacher, at the Woodstock Indian School.

I agree with this teacher, as the population of the Woodstock Reserve is increasing rapidly and, as stated in her letter, the desks are at the present time too close to the front and back of the room leaving no room for even a class on the floor.

I brought this to your attention on May 22, 1942, when the number on the roll was only 24. Now if there was room enough for them there would be at least 40 during the coming year, and this number would increase yearly.

I believe a new school house would be the only solution as it costs so much to remodel an old one. Besides water and sewerage should be an addition to this school.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, December 12, 1945.

Memorandum:

- Director -

The following is a report on my visit to the New Brunswick West Agency November 6-9 inclusive.

WOODSTOCK RESERVE

Population 167;
Area, 152 acres;
65 miles from Fredericton;
Post Office and railway station,
Woodstock 8½ miles (West Bank of the St. John River).

SCHOOL

This is a very good building. Sister Dolores is in charge, assisted by Sister Marian Theresa. There are thirty-seven pupils in attendance. The school is crowded. Additional seats will be sent from the Kingsclear School. The children were clean, well-dressed and well-fed. The last time the inside of the school was painted Indian Agent Whalen donned overalls and worked with the painter, which reduced the cost of the work considerably. As at other schools in New Brunswick, the school children accompanied their parents to Maine to pick potatoes. Definitely this practice must be discouraged in the future.

J. E. Morris,
Welfare Division.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Woodstock Indian School.

Classes for the smaller children of the Woodstock Indian School are being held in the basement, as the school room is too small to accommodate all the children.

The basement floor is made of cement and the Sister says she finds it damp, and has asked that a wooden floor be placed over the cement one.

The cost of this floor complete, would be in the vicinity of $100.00, but on account of the dampness in the basement, and the lack of space in the school room, this floor is really a necessity, and I would strongly recommend that authority be given to have the floor put down before the beginning of another school term.

Edward Whalen,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Vouchers #37 & 38, dated January 10, 1948, in favour of the Woodstock Woodworking Factory for materials and Tom Griffin for labour, repairing the Woodstock Indian School.

These vouchers, which cover labour and materials used in enlarging the basement room of the Woodstock Indian Day School are much more than I had anticipated.

When the work was partly done, I visited the school, and the carpenter, Tom Griffin, who had done the work in the St. Mary's Indian School basement and who is very reliable, stated that it was a mistake that I did not fix the school the same as I had the St. Mary's Indian School, as it would cost less now than later on, and the Sister had wished to have it fixed the same as the other school.

I told Mr. Griffin and the Sister that I had authority to spend $125.00 only on the school, and would have to get authority before I could spend more. He seemed to have misunderstood me in some way, because when I returned to the school again, he had completed the job (with the exception of painting), which is still undone, and the bills were as attached to the above numbered vouchers.

This room is large enough now to have meetings for Homemaker's Clubs or other gatherings of the adults. This is what Sister Marion Teresa had been wanting.

The room in the basement was necessary on account of the overcrowded school room upstairs. I had written to Ottawa about this crowded condition on a previous occasion and Inspector Brooks, the Inspector of the N.B. Schools for that area had mentioned to me that the school room was too small to accommodate the number of pupils.

The smaller pupils had been taught in the basement for the past two years. At times, the room was very damp, and water drop would (over)
gather on the cement walls and dampness on the floor. It was for this reason that I asked for authority to repair the room.

I feel that the Indian Affairs Branch will be satisfied with the improvement, and I would strongly recommend that these vouchers be paid.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

The above numbered voucher in favour of Walden L. Scott is for 2' furnace wood purchased for the Woodstock Indian Day School.

It cost about twice as much to heat the Woodstock School this year, as I had planned, and also twice as much as other years. Although, Ray Hall appeared to be doing his best to supply this school with wood, the quality and quantity which he purchased locally was everything but satisfactory.

When I visited the Woodstock School the first week in March, and saw such a small amount of wood after having been supplied with so much, I immediately told Mr. Hall to discontinue supplying wood to this school.

On my way from Woodstock I located three cords of nice old growth maple, beech, and yellow birch, which I purchased. I then had Departmental Truck No. 1105 haul this wood to the Woodstock School.

I would recommend that an oil burner be purchased for this school, as the Indians steal the wood from the school. Last year authority was granted to purchase an oil burner, but no supply of oil could be obtained at that time. I have for acknowledgement your letter of April 19, regarding the purchase of an oil burner and the burning of oil in the Woodstock Indian School.

The Imperial Oil dealer, now informs me that the prospects for oil during the season 1948-49 are not as bright as they were earlier in the season. Monsieur,

Je dois vous soumettre certain fait et une suggestion en rapport avec l'instruction des enfants qui fréquentent l'Ecole de Bersimis.

Je constate que les élèves de tous les âges ne font pas les progrès qu'ils devraient. Il ne faut pas en attribuer le blâme aux institutrices, dont la méthode d'enseignement ne semble très bonne, et le dévouement inlassable. Les raisons en sont plutôt dues aux difficultés spéciales de l'enseignement aux sauvages et au trop grand nombre d'élèves répartis dans les deux seules classes que nous avons.

Si l'on considère, en effet, le peu d'aptitudes qu'ont les sauvages pour l'étude; le fait qu'ils ne parlent que le Sauvage à leur entrée à l'école; le fait aussi que les parents ne s'occupent nullement de l'avancement de leurs enfants; qu'ils ne s'occupent même pas de savoir s'ils se rendent en classe; encore bien moins de les faire étudier à la maison, nous comprenons facilement le surcroit de besogne que doivent s'imposer les maîtresses. Si je puis vous donner plus de renseignements sur cette question, je le ferai avec plaisir. Vous pouvez aussi correspondre, avec les Rvds Peres de la Mission qui se feront sûrement un devoir de vous donner leurs points de vue à ce sujet ainsi que les institutrices actuelles.
