Sir,

I wish to inform you of certain facts and to make a suggestion concerning the education of children following the Creekin school.

I find that the pupils of all ages do not make as much progress as they should. The blame must not be at-tributed to the teachers whose methods of teaching seem very good and their devotion incessant. The rea-sons are from several difficulties in teaching to Indians; and to the very large number of pupils distributed in the only two class rooms that we have.

In fact, if we consider, the small aptitude the Indians have for studies; the fact that they only speak their Indian tongue when they enter school, and also the fact that their parents do not care for the advancement of their children; that they even do not care if they go to school at all; and that they care less to have them study at home, we can easily understand the strain the teachers had to go through. If we also consider that this year the only two teachers we have had 83 pupils register, with an average attendance of 70 to 75 children, we then understand that the pupils cannot make much progress. At 13 or 14 years of age, that is when the young Indian has become strong enough to work and he abandons school, the children can only read and write a little and in fact after two or three years they forget it all and the result is that they return to their savage state and forget whatever education they had gained. They then only speak their native language and remain strangers to civilization as if they had never been to school.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6070, file 300-1, part 1)
This is, I believe, a great difficulty which causes us to remain at the same point concerning the advancement and civilization of the Indians.

What I wish to suggest is not contrary with the program of economy you are following. I know that, however, if we look up the situation from the right angle and think of the future, the conclusion is quite different. As long as the Indians remain as they are, it will be necessary to assist their old and sick people and maintain expensive organizations to help them along. It is our duty only by education that we will teach them to earn their living like others, to be economical, to save for their old age, finally to live like civilized people.

That formation can only come to them by the education they gain at school. It is therefore necessary that when they leave school they be learned and educated so that they will retain some of it all their life; it is the only way to obtain some improvement from one generation to another.

I am giving all these explanations to make you understand fully the nature of my suggestions and the importance of the latter.

The teachers have each too many pupils, and notwithstanding their good will and devotion, they have not the time and to do all that is necessary to instruct and educate their children in a satisfactory manner.

In the five months I have been here, it is the first time I submit this question to your approval, because I have taken the time necessary to study the facts and the situation.

It would consequently be opportune to appoint a third teacher for the next school term. The Reverend Father Superior and the Rev. Benedict Fathers
the Mission to whom I have said a word about it had thought of this before I did, and believe with me that such action is imperative.

It would be necessary for what to transform a part of the unused space of the ground floor to transfer the Chapel there; this would cost from $300 to $350. And the space occupied now by the chapel could be turned into a class room; it would only be necessary for that to purchase benches and desks.

Anyway the ever-increasing number of children will force us to do this in 1922 if we do not do it this year.

I consequently strongly insist on the importance I should say the necessity of this reform. One will see by the annual report that farming does not make any progress here; the reason is that the true Indians do not want to do anything else but hunting. It is only by civilizing them that we will give them the taste of farming or of any other kind of work; and once more civilized they will come to them in direct line with their intellectual development, and such development can only be acquired at the school.

I should give you more detailed information on the question I would do so with pleasure. You can write to the Reverend Brother Father of the Mission who would be pleased to give you their point of view on the matter as well as the teachers themselves.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to providing increased classroom accommodation for the Indian children at Bersimis. The number of children enrolled and receiving instruction from the two teachers at present employed has been noted.

Monsieur,

Au début de l'année scolaire 1931-1932, je vous demandais de m'aider à donner une troisième année afin de décharger les deux autres classes qui étaient trop chargées d'élèves, ce qui rendait leur progrès impossible et dont tout le monde se plaignait.

Le Département n'a pas jugé bon, pour le moment, d'accepter ma demande. L'année prochaine, M'a-t-on dit, nous avons accordé cette matinée pour concevoir la classe et comptant sur cette première que doit se réaliser cette année, nous avons fait notre part et j'espère que le Département fera la même affaire.

Notre communauté a joué une troisième sourc qui était absolument nécessaire pour éviter que les deux autres soient inutiles et provoquer aux élèves la facilité de faire beaucoup de progrès. Nous avons ouvert une troisième classe que se compose d'indiens et de Canadiens qui ont leur licence pour rester sur la réserve. Vous ne sauriez croire tout le bien que cela a fait. Dans les trois classes il s'est fait un travail excellent et les progrès sont le double des années dernières. Tout le monde éprouve une véritable satisfaction. Les dirigeants d'abord,

At the end of the scholar year of 1931 I, Sister Marie du Carmel, director of the school of Betsiamits, requested you to kindly give us a third teacher so as to reduce the other two classrooms which were overcrowded with pupils, as this was rendering progress impossible and because of difficulties of which everyone was complaining.

The Department did not judge it proper at that moment to grant my request. Next year, I was told, we will give you that additional teacher. To ease up matters and relying on that promise, which is to be brought to effect this year, we have done our part and we hope that the Department will do his at present.

Our community has supplied a third Sister which was absolutely necessary to help the other two teachers and to give the pupils a chance to make some progress. We have opened a third classroom which is composed of Indian and Canadian children who have their permit to reside on the reserve. You can hardly imagine all the good that this has done. In the three classrooms an excellent work has been accomplished and the progress has been double that of preceding years. Everyone is enjoying real satisfaction. The teachers, first, are not overworked, the authorities, religious and civil, the chief of the Agent and also the parents appreciate the high value of this third classroom.
All this is very fine and very good; it is even indispensable as the pupils are too numerous now to be crowded in two rooms. Now the other problem arises. We need to keep this teacher and she should have at least a small salary. The Canadians who are contributing this school have brought their contributions but this is insufficient. If the Department on its side would contribute its share and give us at least $200.00 per year, we can continue this task. I am certainly not too exacting; and I hope, with confidence, that I will be granted this favour soon as you will understand that this is of absolute necessity. Consequently, teachers and pupils will bring all their efforts to profit from the generosity and courtesy of the officers of the Department for the favour which has been given to us.

And, as we have done for the last thirty years, we will continue to be for these children, who are entrusted to us, devoted teachers and will conduct them and help them to be good women and distinguished citizens according to their condition.

In advance I thank you very sincerely for what you may do in consideration of our pupils and ourselves.

Very humbly yours,

Monsieur,

En réponse à la votre no. 3-1-1, datée 13 juillet 1932 je dois vous dire que lors de mon voyage à Ottawa, au dépôt des Affaires Indiennes, l'été dernier nous avons longuement discuté et résolu cette question d'une école pour les canadiens. Vous en étiez arrivé à la conclusion que si cette troisième classe était avantageuse pour les indiens et si ces avantages pouvaient être constatés après une année d'expérience vous payeriez le salaire de cette troisième maîtresse. Nous avons l'expérience d'une année. Les canadiens ont payé seuls, cinq familles, le salaire complet de l'institutrice cette année. Les résultats obtenus par l'inauguration de cette troisième classe ont dépassé nos espérances. Dix-huit enfants canadiens en ont grandement bénéficié. En outre en décongestionnant les classes des indiens cela a permis de créer une division spéciale pour les élèves indiens les plus avancés. Vous avez déjà payé pour envoyer des jeunes sauvagesses dans des couvents à Rimouski. Cette dépense ne sera plus nécessaire à l'avenir parce ayant trois institutrices, celle qui s'occupe des canadiens s'occupera en même temps de la division la plus avancée des indiens. Le degré d'instruction pourra y être poussé autant qu'il le serait dans une maison d'enseignement extérieure.

Vous pouvez vous enquérir directement auprès de notre père missionnaire des bienfaiteurs résultats que nous a fournis cette année l'ouverture d'une nouvelle classe; c'est lui en effet qui a dirigé et contrôlé cette classe cette année.

Vous pouvez voir par le dernier rapport trimestriel de l'école, qu'étant donné le nombre toujours croissant d'élèves l'engagement d'une troisième maîtresse s'imposait.

Les canadiens sont prêts pour les années futures de faire leur part pour le maintien de cette troisième institutrice. Sir,

I reply to yours No. 3-1-1, dated the 13th July 1932. I wish to say that during my trip to Ottawa, at the Dept. of Indian Affairs, last summer, we have discussed at length and solved the question of a school for the Canadians. You came to the conclusion that if that third classroom was advantageous for the Indians and if the benefit could be appreciated after a year of experiment, you would pay the salary of the third teacher. We have now the experience of a year. The Canadians have paid about their salary of the teacher this year; it was shared by five families. The results obtained by the opening of this third room have been far above our expectations. Eighteen Canadian children have benefited greatly by it. This has removed the congestion in the other classrooms for the Indians and has permitted to create a special division for the advanced Indians properly. You have paid in the past to send young squaws to the convent of Brimstone. Such expenditure will not be necessary in future because having 3 teachers, the one who will be in charge of the Canadians will also look over the advanced division of the Indians. The degree of instruction can be advanced as much as it is in an outside school.

You can inquire directly from our Reverend Missionary if the good results which have followed the opening of the new room this year, in fact he controls and directs that class himself.

You can see by the last quarterly report of the school, that in consideration of the increasing number of pupils the third mistress was a necessity.

The Canadians are ready to pay their share of the maintenance of the third teacher in future. The latter
is a Sister of the same community of those who were appointed at first. She has the perfect accommodation at the school.

I consequently strongly recommend the expenditure of $200.00 for the appointment of another mission in the fall. I have the assurance from the Canadians that they will pay the balance which may amount to $150 or $157.00

As school inspector of all the White Children schools in our mission's limits, Bersimis Reserve's White Canadian class included, I have been advised lately by Rev. Sister Superior of Bersimis Convent, Sister Ste-Jeanne, that Sister St-Marc teaching our Canadian students has not received her usual monthly cheque of twenty dollars for the month of January, whilst the other two Sisters have received theirs. I have reasons to suppose he did. But what I can't understand, is it really the fact, is that the Department should have cut that auxiliary fund right in the middle of a school year and without giving any notice to Sister Superior of the Convent... A few years ago, in 1932, Sister Marie du Carmel, then Superior of Bersimis Convent school, had requested that a grant of two hundred dollars be provided towards the salary of a third teacher at the Bersimis Indian School; and the said sum was granted and paid until last January; but that was only part of the teacher's salary; the other part being paid by the few White families living on the Reserve. At the time the said sum was granted, there were three students in the said class whose mother was a squaw; two of those students are still going to that same class. Moreover, it was also supposed that the Department had granted the said fund on the ground that in the future instead of sending Bersimis Indian pupils to convent schools in Rimouski, like it was already done in the past, those pupils could join that third class if they kept on going to school long enough to reach the higher divisions, at least the fifth and sixth Grade. But so far none of them, except the half-breed students above mentioned, have been able to go further than the third Grade; when they reach there, they generally quit school....

Nevertheless I beg the Department to continue in the future to pay that third teacher the usual auxiliary fund of twenty dollars a month. Otherwise, as the White families are very few on the Reserve and some of them not very rich and thus can't very well afford to pay a teacher's total salary, we'll have to close that third class; and probably send the sister, teacher of the said class, back to Chicoutimi, and distribute all the white pupils (twenty-six in all, if I am not mistaken) between the other two classes, like it used to be before that third class was opened; but let me tell you, the two classes will soon be crowded, on account of the white students being three or four times more numerous now than in the past years before 1932.

THE SECRETARY OF STATE OF CANADA

Ottawa, July 31, 1940

My Dear Colleague,

I am just informed by His Excellency Bishop N.A. Labrie, Apostolic Vicar of the Gulf of St. Lawrence, that the Department of Indian Affairs had decided to close the school of the Betsiamites Indian Reserve during the winter season on the plea of economy.

I do not know if this matter of economy is the real reason for the decision, but I wish to protest energetically against any attempt on the part of the authorities of the Department to limit to the summer season the educational means for the inhabitants of that locality.

The white people of the reserve will be greatly affected by this action, and I may add that even Indians will suffer very much. I perfectly understand that they cannot all attend the school in winter, but on the other hand the number who is taking advantage is large enough to warrant the complete maintenance of this school during the whole school year.

You will agree with me that there should be more serious circumstances than those we are suffering just now to deprive in such a way these people from the educational means they are enjoying.

I would ask you therefore, to give your personal attention to this important matter and I know that you will not allow this decision to be carried out, especially during a time when the most perfect harmony and complete co-operation are so needed.

Sincerely yours,

Hon. T.A. Grégoire
Minister of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

(Sgd.) Pierre Casgrain.

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum enclosing letter received by the Minister from the Honourable Mr. Casgrain, Secretary of State, with reference to the closing of the Bersimis Indian Day School.

Dear Sir,

With further reference to securing teachers for a seasonal school at Bersimis, in 1941, I beg to inform you that I have not as yet obtained a definite answer from Les Soeurs du Bon Conseil, of Chicoutimi, about their terms.

In spite of the school being closed the building, nevertheless, has to be heated on account of the lighting plant being installed in this building to prevent the batteries from freezing. Moreover, the hospital building gets its supply of water through a pump also installed in the school building. To keep the school building unheated would require a change in the installation of the lighting system and the water pump which could be done only at great expense. I, therefore, beg to suggest that the Department reconsider its decision and that the school reopen October 1st next until the end of June, 1941.

I am pretty sure to be able to get two teachers for a total amount of $700.00 for an academic year of nine months, thus saving $400.00 per annum, which would make up for the expense of the coal and wood.

I beg to request that the school be kept open for nine months to begin October 1st, this fall, and that I be authorized to get two teachers at the above terms.

LeDevoir, Montreal, September 8, 1941.

Unknown Tragedy

Unknown by most people, in any case.

The matter has to do with the lot of the Indians of Betsiamites, on the North Shore. And it is a contributor to the Progres du Saguenay, of Chicoutimi, who reveals to us, in a quite recent travel narrative, this sad adventure.

It is painful, he states (PROGRES of September 4) to note the miserable condition of the Indian village of Betsiamites, and it is all the more painful since everything is still redolent of the prosperity that reigned there a few years ago. Spacious and trim houses in design, but in a state of delapidation, some closed, others bearing the scars of age and the lack of upkeep; sidewalks half-rotted; fallen or shaky fences, flower-beds in a state of abandon, where a few flowers still stubbornly survive amidst weeds and undergrowth. Even the public buildings bear the imprint of this increasing desolation. The presbytery reminds one of a kind of elegance in tatters whose former splendor only survives in its appearance and the cordial hospitality and cleanliness of its interior. The hospital is pitiful to see. The Indian school, though of recent construction, suffers from the want of needed repairs and would be a ruin were it not for the wonders worked in the care the sisters of the Bon Conseil know how to bestow upon it.

This misery is reflected too in the dress and demeanor of the Indians. Twenty years ago, we are told, the Papisnachois, of Betsiamits, constituted the smartest portion of the Eastern Indian tribes. Vigorous and proud, with an unfailing good humour, owning a hunting territory that yielded up to $500,000 and even $600,000 in furs; they were prosperous on all counts and it showed in what accounts for the luxurious residences that look pitiful now, that good taste and that discretion which one still finds amongst them in spite of their present poverty. It seems that these poor Indians are virtually dying of hunger. Their country devastated by intruding hunters who have been invading it for the past twenty years, now only yields from $30,000 to $35,000 in pelts; and the scanty allowance the government gives them is insufficient to sustain them properly. Able-bodied hunters are capable of getting along by their own means, but the others, the resident families especially, have nothing to do but the wolf away from the door. As a matter of fact, their population is diminishing at an alarming rate; and it is a great pity, for Canada has more reasons than one to wish for the preservation and prosperity of this fine and interesting tribe which feeds an important commercial enterprise.

The contributor to the PROGRES states that the people are beginning to entertain some hope in this
connection. It is expected that the steps taken by monsignor Labrie, apostolic vicar of the region and former missionary at Betsiamits, will secure good results.

Let us hope so wholeheartedly.

Le Devoir, Montreal, September 8, 1941.

Peculiar Economy

One knows that, on the pretext that everything must make way before the needs of the war, certain people are ready to practise the oddest economies.

"...On the pretext of economy, states the contributor to the PROGRES, the Indian children of Betsiamits are deprived of schools. The government (it is the Dominion Government) has just decided as a matter of fact, "on account of the war", that their school will be closed as from September 15 and will not operate during the four summer months. Here are the children of a whole population deprived of schooling; the development of a whole generation sacrificed, for a petty saving. It is extremely unfortunate".

It is extremely unfortunate, and this decision takes on the complexion of a sinister maliciousness when one remembers that the government finds at the same time the means of paying for a publicity that tells the whole country that Miss X. shews gum, but does it elegantly, that her day's work done she returns to her boarding-house and takes a bath, that she has no fellow in Toronto because the man of her dreams is a policeman in Montreal. (All that, as the Survivance, of Edmonton, recalled it, was forwarded to the newspapers, for publication, by the Federal Information Bureau.

Frankly, there are a certain number of Canadians who, in order that the little Indian children of Betsiamits should have regular classes, would willingly agree to be forever deprived of the precious information on the ways and customs and the sentimental preferences of Miss X.

O.H.

LE DEVOIR — Tragédie économique

Inconnue de la plupart, en tout cas...

Il s'agit du sort des missions de Betsiamits, sur la rivière Nord. Et c'est un collage tiré du Progrès du Saguenay de Chicoutimi, qui nous révèle, dans un récit de voyage tout récent, cette triste réalité.

Il est impossible, dit-il (Progrès du 4 septembre), de constater l'état misérable du village indien de Betsia-

mists, et d'admirer plus pénible que tout serait encore de la prospérité qui régnait là il y a quelques années. Maisons spacieuses et coquettes, fermes ouvertes en décrépitude, les une fermées, les autres ravagées par le temps et le désordre d'entretien; trottoirs à peine aménagés, clôtures érodées ou brisantes, parterres à l'abandon, où quelques fleurs s'obstinent à survivre, entre les herbes folles et les brossettes. Les édifices publics eux-mêmes portent le cachet de cette vétusté décadente. Le grenier fait place à une sorte de prison en maillons dont l'ancienne splendeur ne survit qu'à la physionomie de l'endroit. L'hospitalité continue et la propreté de son intérieur. L'hôpital fait pitié. L'école, elle, est de date plus récente, manque de ressources nécessaires et serait une ruine sous les prodiges de soins qui savent lui donner les religieuses du Bon-Conseil qui l'habitaient.

Cette misère apparaît également dans la costume et dans l'attitude des Indiens. Il y a vingt ans, nous dit-on, les Papinachois de Betsiamists étaient les plus beaux porteurs des territoires intérieurs de l'Est. Vigoureux et fiers, d'une inaltérable gaîté, en possession d'un terrain fertile, de quelques fonds de terre, jusqu'à 150000 et même 600000 de fourrures, ils étaient prospères à tous points de vue et cela ne suffisait pas à expliquer leur existence luxueuses, qui sont pitié maintenant, ce bon goût et cette tenue qu'on retrouve encore chez eux. La pauvreté actuelle, il paraît que ces pauvres Indiens meurent pratiquement de faim, le pays, occupé par les nouveaux immigrants qui l'ont envahi depuis une vingtaine d'années, ne produit plus que pour 30000 à 25000 de fourrures, et la faible pitance que leur donne le gouvernement ne suffit pas à les sustenter correctement. Les chasses valides peuvent être tirées d'affaire par leurs propres moyens, mais les autres, les milliers restants, ne survivent pas et ne se refont pas leur vie. En fait, leur population décroît de façon alarmante; et c'est grand dommage car le Canada a plus d'une raison...
Singulière économie

On dit que, sous prétexte que tout doit céder devant les nécessités de guerre, certains sont prêts à pratiquer des économies sur les familles.

Sous prétexte d'économie, dit le collaborateur du Progrès, "les cellules de la ville ont été fermées. Les enfants bétisians, le gouvernement, le clergé, le peuple, le Canada, tout est en effet de décider, "à cause de la guerre."

Le service de l'État est interrompu, à partir du 15 septembre et ne fonctionne plus. Voilà les enfants de toutes les familles privés de toute une génération sacrifiée, pour une année ou deux seulement malheureux.

C'est un profond mépris, et cela prend une allure de cocasserie sinistre quand on sait que le gouvernement trouve en même temps le moyen de payer une pension qui ne suffit pas à nourrir Mlle X, mère de la famille, mais, avec elle, elle retourne à la pension prendre son bain, qu'elle veut faire elle-même à l'hôtel parce que l'homme de son rêve est un agent de police. Mlle X, qui a été une fois l'objet d'un rapport de la Surveillance d'Edmonton, a été examinée par le Service d'immigration, par le Service fédéral de l'Immigration.

Franchement, il est un certain nombre de Canadiens qui pensent que les parents indiens de Betsiamits aient des classes régulières, après avoir été exposés à la prière de ces précieux renseignements sur les us, coutumes et préférences sentimentales de Mlle X.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY.

BERSIMIS INDIANS

The Peribonca Beaver and Fur Preserve covers an area of 10,000 square miles, of which slightly more than half is on hunting lands of Bersimis Indians, who will benefit greatly when it comes into production.

This must be "the steps taken by Monsignor Labrie" who was greatly instrumental in having the preserve set aside for the Indians. The money expended, however, and the management comes from our Branch.

Figures quoted for former fur production ($50,000 per year) applies only to a few years when the Indians killed off nearly all the fur-bearers on their hunting grounds because of white encroachment and no records will show a sustained yield of anything more than 1/10 of that figure.

The quoted figure, $50,000, for present production of furs amounts to $50.00 per year for each married man, which for a person who has no rent to pay, no meat or fish or fuel to buy removes him from any danger of starvation.

References in text:

References to houses well taken except that closed houses are a sign only that Indians have left for their hunting lands.

Sidewalks:- Not half rotten but certainly in need of repair.

Fallen fences:- Certainly not the affair of Department.

Hospital and School:- Description grossly exaggerated. Care-taking done by Indian caretaker employed by Department.

Flower Gardens:- Only two in the village - Mrs. Barolet's, due to her own industry, very flourishing. The other in front of the church is not the responsibility of the Department.

Their country devastated by white hunters:- This is substantially correct but local M.L.A. refused to consider our request to extend the Preserve further into his constituency because he did not want to antagonize them.

Virtually dying of hunger:- See 3rd paragraph which presents subsistence level.

Resident families:- There are no farms at Bersimis, so the only resident families are those too lazy to hunt.

Population diminishing?
Ottawa, September 19, 1941.

My dear Colleague:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 11 and also copies of two Press articles that appeared in "Le Devoir", Montreal, of September 8, 1941, attached thereto.

The departmental records indicate that the Bersimis Indian Agency had an Indian population of 704 (1924 census) and a population of 689 (1931 census). It will thus be seen that the population has remained practically stationary in recent years.

The Indians of Bersimis have at this date Trust Funds amounting to $145,444.80 Capital Account and $5,377.21 Interest Account, or a total of $150,822.01. Relief distributed to the Bersimis Indians from these funds during the last fiscal year amounted to $5,698.00. In addition to this, relief covering the same period was distributed from parliamentary appropriation amounting to $3,060.38.

These Indians are, as you know, engaged almost exclusively in hunting and trapping. The latest report received from the Indian agent indicates that, last year, the earnings for each trapper from this source amounted to $350.00.

You will be interested to learn that we have recently secured from the Quebec Government an area to be known as the Peribonka Beaver and Fur Preserve. This area consists of 15,600 square miles and at least one half of the area will be assigned to hunting and trapping for the members of the Bersimis Band. Steps have already been taken by the Department

Honourable Pierre Cassain,
Secretary of State,
Ottawa.

for the conservation of wild life on this preserve. Thirty-nine men have been engaged and will be permanently employed in the area as game guardians. This is the first constructive development, aimed at the re-establishment of the Bersimis Indians on a self-supporting basis, that has been undertaken at any time in recent years.

I regret that I cannot at this time state definitely when this area will be re-opened for hunting and trapping. Our field officers estimate that, if there is a normal increase of beaver in the territory, trapping should be permitted at the end of a 6 year period. These officers assure us that the conservation policy of the Government now in force in the Bersimis district should, in the course of a few years, result in raising the average Indian's catch of furs from a value of approximately $250.00 to a fur catch worth at least $1,000.00 per annum.

I note with interest a reference in the newspaper article to a time when this territory yielded $100,000 and even $200,000 in furs. It is just possible that this is a reference to a period when the white trapper invaded the area and to a time when the Indian, alarmed by the white man's encroachment, hastened to trap every fur-bearing animal available, regardless of the future. The unrestricted trapping of furs in those years has been largely responsible for the comparatively small catch and the resulting loss of revenue to the Indians in later years.

The Bersimis Indians have had for a number of years a lease on certain fishing grounds. These fishing grounds extend from the mouth of the Bersimis river to High Falls - a distance of 40 miles. During the 10 year period 1922-1931 the Indian Affairs Branch paid to the province of Quebec, from Indian band funds, for these fishing rights, $1,500 per year, or a total of $15,000. A new agreement entered into with the Quebec Government in the year 1932 resulted in a reduction of the license fee charged, from $1,500 to $750 per year. This amount has been paid annually during the last 8 years, amounting to a total of $6,750.00.

The needs -
The needs of the hunting and trapping Indians from an educational standpoint have been carefully and sympathetically reviewed from time to time by the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch who, as you know, work in close cooperation with the church authorities. I am personally disposed to think that we have not yet succeeded in the preparation of a course of study adapted to the needs of these comparatively primitive people. The Department has been subjected, and is still being subjected, to a great deal of criticism for the policy that aims at keeping the children of hunting and trapping Indians in Indian day or residential schools from the time they are 6 until they are 16 years old. This long sojourn in school, we are assured by the critics, results in rendering the Indian youth almost useless as a guide or trapper. It has been recommended from time to time that children be sent to school during the summer months for a period of three or four months and that the male pupils be permitted to accompany their families on the hunting excursions that take place during the fall and winter months. By way of experiment, therefore, we have been operating a number of summer schools, I am glad to state, somewhat successfully, in the northern sections of the Dominion.

The operation of the Bersimis Indian Day School was carefully reviewed by the officials of the Department, following the receipt of a report from Inspector Jude Thibault, dated October 13, 1928. The Bersimis School had at that time an enrolment of approximately 67 pupils. It was noted by the officials that 40 tons of coal, purchased at the rate of $17.00 per ton, were necessary to heat the school building. This heating cost appeared to be, and still appears to be, out of all proportion to the cost usually borne by the Department for heating Indian day schools. It was noted, also, that the attendance showed a drastic reduction during the winter months and that this reduction was due wholly to the departure of a large number of Indian pupils who accompanied their parents to the hunting grounds. We did not feel that we were justified, in a period as critical as the one in which
we find ourselves, in keeping this school in operation during the winter months, in view of the attendance and the amount of fuel necessary to keep the building heated. This decision does not mean, however, that it is our intention to operate the Bersimis School on a 4 months basis indefinitely. The educational needs of the Indian population will come under review from time to time, and if it is considered economically sound to undertake the reconstruction of the building in a manner that would reduce heating costs, there is no reason why the school term should not be gradually extended, provided the attendance from year to year justifies such extension.

I have been informed that the Inspector of Indian Agencies for the Province of Quebec will visit Bersimis and undertake a thorough inspection of conditions at the agency, early in October. It is scarcely necessary to add that immediately following the receipt of the Inspector's report, the educational and other needs of the Indian population will again be very carefully and very sympathetically reviewed.

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum for file:

Rt. Rev. Napoleon Labrie, Vicar Apostolic of the Gulf of St. Laurence, interviewed Mr. Hoey and myself this morning with reference to the Bersimis Indian Day School. The Bishop pointed out that a number of the Indian families at Bersimis do not go trapping in the winter and, as a result, there are 30 or 40 children of school age who are not receiving any training. Consequently he strongly urged that arrangements be made to re-open the Bersimis School for the full academic period each year.

Mr. Hoey pointed out to the Bishop the reasons for only operating a summer school. One of the very heavy expenditures was the purchase of coal.

After discussing the matter fully it was decided to have Mr. Dube, a contractor of Rimouski, make an estimate of the cost of insulating the present Bersimis School in order to conserve the heat and explore the possibility of cutting off part of the building for winter use. This would naturally involve less heating. The Bishop expects that Mr. Dube will be at Bersimis in either April or May and Mr. Hoey promised the Bishop that at that time Inspector Thibault would also go to Bersimis and be with Mr. Dube when he is preparing his estimate of what could be done to make the building habitable for the winter.

The Bishop also suggested that the Indians should be made responsible for supplying the wood required for heating the building and Mr. Thibault will be instructed to interview them with regard to this matter.

rait cette dépense une fois pour longtemps, dans l'intérêt de M. l'agent qui ne serait plus à faire de nouvelles réclamations et surtout dans l'intérêt de nos pauvres petits indiens qui sont sans classe et sans formation.

Betsiamites, July 30, 1943.

To the Secretary:

Since my return to the mission on May 15th, I had hoped to spend the winter with our Indian children, but my hopes now seem to vanish. We should know how what you intend to do in order that we may inform our Sister Superior accordingly or prepare to spend the winter here.

I greatly regret that, as it appears to us, the report made by Inspector Thibault has been set aside. I have been living in this house for 15 years and I should therefore be in a position to judge of Mr. Dubé's proposals made before witnesses and approved by Inspector Thibault. If I were allowed to advise the departmental authorities, I would ask them to accept those proposals without delay for it would be in the Department's and in the Agent's interests to do so. Moreover, the Agent would cease putting in new claims and, above all, the Indian children, who are without classroom and tuition, would greatly profit by them.

Inspector Doucet intends to do much less, but if his proposals are accepted, we may expect to suffer from the cold next winter as never before in case we remain. A coat of paint in the interior would not prevent the cold from entering through the bricks and around the windows where the cement has chipped off. Would it not be possible to repair the outside and wait for better years to decorate the interior?

We trust that we shall hear from you soon and that you will advise us of our appointment for the current year.

Havre St. Pierre, March 8th, 1944.

Hon. T. A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Monsieur le ministre:

Allow me to write you again on the matter of the Betsiamites Indian school. I had spoken to you about it last year in my last correspondence and I told you that I would bring the matter up again.

Repairs have been made during the course of the summer. They are not as complete as we would have desired but nevertheless they should constitute a considerable saving in fuel economy. Unfortunately this school remained closed all Winter.

Reverend Father Sirois, missionary at Betsiamites, reports to me that this winter there remains on the reservation 15 boys and 13 girls of school age. In this province we maintain a school in operation for 8 and sometimes 6 children. I do not see why the Dept. of Indian Affairs would not give the same care to children who are under its protection.

You might tell me that their brothers who accompany the parents when they go hunting have no school. But the living conditions are not the same. Those who are in the bush forcibly cannot have any school, but they do not have the same occasions of spoiling their education. They are alone with their parents and it is a fact that the Indian parents in bush camps look after their children. They even teach them to read and the rudiments of religion. In the village, unfortunately, they give them less care and the liberty enjoyed by those children often turns to vagrancy. With the facilities of meeting strangers and therefore being corrupted those children do not constitute a moral and intellectual contribution for the reservation, but rather they are agents of corruption for the others when they come back from the forest.

With a good school which would be permanently open, those children would get better formation and a few
among them would get a chance of having a happy influence on their fellow-citizens.

We recognize the successful efforts of your department in the hunting field. But we will not eternally count on hunting to support our Indians, at least not all. The coming industrialization of the region will give them new outlets. Would it not be proper to use vision and to give, by way of schools, our young girls a domestic economy formation and our boys a preparation at an industrial school. Those things are not impossible even for our Indians and I think that your administration must be interested in them as part of the solicitude which you wish to show those Indians. But I affirm particularly that without the school we will not obtain the standard of morality which we also wish and which honours all races.

Consequently, Honourable Minister, I insist with all my strength upon the fact that the nuns who will come back in the Spring, remain at their post all through the coming winter and all the following ones. One nun will be sufficient for the few children who will be at Betsiamites.

We are not making this request for the children of French nationality. If there is the need of another nun for them, we shall pay her and she will teach school in another place, if you so desire. But it is simply the future (or lot) of our Indians which prompts us to address ourselves to you with confidence.

Hoping, honourable Sir, that my request will be received with all the kindness which was shown me last year, when I had the honour of being introduced to you, I assure you of my gratefulness and my sincere devotion.

Very respectfully yours,

N. H. LaBrie, C.J.M.
Apostolic Vicar of the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

(Gulf)

Memorandum:

MR. HOBY:

Re: Inspection of Restigouche and Bersimis

The condition of the teacher's residence did not prove to be as serious as anticipated. On checking the main line of the sewage system, I found it to be clear of any serious obstruction. The trouble was in the building itself. The piping from the kitchen sink was not properly installed. There are no clean out traps installed anywhere. I had the Campbellton plumber, Mr. Walsh, inspect this system and I authorized him to proceed with the necessary changes.

I then proceeded to Bersimis.

Having completed the work on the North shore, I returned to Restigouche to check the completed work. I found the work done according to directions given. If trouble should arise again, the clean outs will permit the plumber to remedy it quickly by means of sewage rods.

The flooding water in the sewing room is due to surface water. The road is higher than the school, forming a dam. The condition could have been temporarily remedied by means of a small ditch draining into the adjoining yard. Steps have been taken to have this defect permanently remedied. The school yard will be drained through the existing sewer system. This work is not yet completed. No man who could do that type of work was available at the time. I had an interview with Mr. Beaulieu who will do the work at his earliest convenience. It is a matter of connecting a pipe from a small reservoir (2'x2' x 2') to the present sewage system.

BERSIMIS

I have made a complete study of the educational facilities at Bersimis. Approximately 2/3 of the pupils go trapping during the season with their parents. If the school term were from September 1st to June 31st the majority of the children would not be able to attend school. I would recommend that the school term be from March 1st to November 15th. This would permit the pupils who remain at Bersimis during the year to have nine months of school and also permit those who leave to trap to attend during their stay at Bersimis.

Organized games should be an integrated part of school work not only to improve the health of the children but also to teach them co-operation. Moreover, games will make school more attractive and will tend to increase the attendance.
Very little change will be necessary to the heating system. The heating coils in the auditorium should be disconnected. Instructions were left with the acting Indian Agent to do this. I would recommend that birch be used as fuel as much as possible, as it is quite plentiful on the north shore and the price, I feel, would be quite reasonable. This could be supplemented with a few tons of coal for the coldest periods. This, I believe, would reduce the cost of heating this school.

I was somewhat disappointed that Reverend Father Sirois of Bersimis was away on his missions. However, on Saturday, July 1st, I met His Lordship Bishop LeBrie in Quebec city. I explained to him that we were ready to introduce a nine month period starting on March 1 and to conclude about the middle of November. He readily saw the purpose of this arrangement and expressed his satisfaction.

I explained to His Lordship the Department's integrated programme of study. He was agreeably surprised. He did not imagine that the Department had evolved such a splendid training for the Indians. I informed him that the Department was ready to introduce adult education such as, sewing clubs, provided the teaching personnel were qualified to conduct this type of work. Material and incidentals would be supplied by the Department. All the Department asks in return is reasonable results in education. In raising Bishop LeBrie expressed the wish that I get in touch with the Mother Superior of the "Soeurs du Bon Conseil" at Chicoutimi. He wishes to receive all our literature on education. I believe, His Lordship was quite pleased with the proposed solution of the Bersimis problem.

At Chicoutimi, I interviewed the Mother Superior of the "Soeurs du Bon Conseil" and I discussed with her very frankly the difficulties at Bersimis. She expressed the opinion that a great deal of the difficulties were due to misunderstanding. I suggested that she visit Bersimis and make a thorough study of the conditions at the school. The Department, I explained, is not looking for perfection, but is only seeking improvement from year to year. She will visit Bersimis in September. I explained to her that the Department was prepared to increase the teaching facilities at Bersimis and was prepared to introduce a term from March 1st to the end of November. Before giving me a definite answer to this proposition the Superior wished to consult her advisors. She will notify us as to her decision in the near future.

I wish to express my sincere appreciation for the splendid cooperation I received from all the officials with whom I had to deal during this survey.

Respectfully submitted,

Monsieur,

En terminant notre année scolaire, il nous fait plaisir de vous faire part de nos activités.

Après avoir étudié ensemble les explications qui nous ont été données sur le système d'instruction, nous avons commencé avec les grands dès le 17 juillet. Au début, les enfants étaient gauches, mais l'attrait du découpage et du dessin leur a fait se mettre à l'œuvre avec entrain. Nous trouvons les résultats très satisfaisants. Ils connaissent maintenant les noms d'une foule de choses qu'ils ont découpe ou dessinée, ils le disent et le répètent, composent des phrases ou reproduisent les scènes que telle phrase...
se explique. Nous faisons de la menuiserie, en carton, ils se sont organisés un magasin général qui nous ferait gagner, avant de partir, construire chacun une échelle de Noël. Un rival était que nous n'avons jamais pu obtenir, nous avons préparé une petite fête pour le Noël où tous nos élèves parlent français.

Avec les élèves je me suis occupé de leur réception après le départ du plus grand nombre. Tout de même ils ont eu le temps d'apprendre une trentaine de mots qu'ils lisent au tableau ouvrent et qu'ils écrivent même en dictée, le dessin les intéresse déjà beaucoup. J'ai acheté quelques livres de lecture pour construire leurs mots et apprendre les lettres nouvelles.

Actuellement nous avons 3 élèves inscrits et qui passeront l'hiver ici. Nos classes sont très confortables au point de vue température surtout depuis que j'ai fait poser des tapis sur les fenêtres par en dessous, je crois que la dépense de charbon serait diminuée de moitié.

Nous partirons bientôt en vacances et tout notre temps sera employé à préparer des moyens de...
mulation et de développement de nos procédés. Nous avons hâte de vous en causer afin de les corriger et de les compléter. Il nous ferait grand plaisir de posséder un exemplaire des livres dont nous avons parlé lorsqu'ils sortiront en anglais. Nous étudierons plus à fond votre système et nous pourrions même préparer une copie de choses utiles pour l'an prochain.

Voilà pour le côté, mais la part des mamans ne sera pas négligée puisque nous devons que nous nous en occupions. Nous passerons nos vacances aux écoles où nous tenons nos cours et où nous ferons tout ce qui nous semblera utile. Avec la culture nous avons pensé que le soin de intéresserait beaucoup. Nous avons assez de difficulté à faire de la laine et la payent très cher. Nous pourrions acheter de la laine cardée et la filerions elles-mêmes. Le métier serait peut-être d'un grand attrait aussi mais comme cela exige beaucoup de choses je laisse à votre discrétion.

Vous avez parlé de machines à coudre, faudra-t-il en faire la demande au département ou si...
pour vous occuper de nous même de nous en procurer des mêmes pour les choses utiles aux élèves. La régulation ne doit advenir qu'en nous et nous commencerons en mars, que devrons nous faire? C'est une des raisons pour lesquelles je désirerais votre visite dès le début de notre année scolaire.

Le vicomte Père Léonard est très enchanté de l'attitude qu'il a eu avec nous. J'en suis heureuse parce que malgré tout ce que nous lui disions il restait très défiant. C'est le seul du pays... comme nous l'avons constaté à votre arrivée, mais cette longue lettre vous fera voir que je suis guérie. Il est temps que je mette un point. Veuillez croire à nos religieuses sentiments à votre égard et à notre entière collaboration à votre œuvre d'éducation chez nos indiens.

En Dieu et Marie,

La Sœur de R.-D. du Bon-Conseil
par Sœur Sainte-Jeanne-sapte

Mr. A. J. Doucet,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

At the termination of our school year, I have pleasure in giving you herewith an account of our activities.

After having studied together the explanations received regarding your teaching system, Sister began with the older ones on the 11th of July. At first the children were awkward, but the fun of cutting out and drawing put them to work with a will. We find the results very satisfactory. They now know the names of a number of things that they have cut out or drawn, they can read them and write them, compose sentences or make pictures illustrating such sentences. They have done some building, in cardboard; have organized a general store, which would make you smile; before leaving each one will construct a crib for Christmas. And, something we have never been able to achieve: we have prepared a little party for the Parish Priest, at which all the pupils speak French.

I did not start with the tiny tots until September, after the greater number had left. Nevertheless, they have had time to learn about thirty names which they can read on the blackboard and even write from dictation; they are already very much interested in drawing. I bought some sets of letters for word-building and teaching them print.

At present we have 31 pupils enrolled, who will spend the winter here. Our classrooms are very comfortable, as regards temperature, especially since I had latches put on the outside of the windows. I believe that the expenditure for coal will be cut in half.

We shall be soon going on vacation and shall spend all our time in working out better methods. We are anxious to talk this over with you before making any definite changes. We should like very much to have a copy of the books of which you have already spoken to us. Even though they were in English, we would thoroughly study your system and could even prepare many useful things for next year.

That is all for the children; but we shall not neglect the mothers, since it is your wish that we see to them. We shall spend our vacation at household science schools run by our Sisters, where we shall acquire anything that would seem useful. Along with sewing, we thought that spinning would interest them very much. It is fairly difficult for them to get wool and they pay a high price for it. We could buy carded wool and they could spin it themselves. Perhaps they would like weaving very much, but many things are needed for that, so I leave it to your discretion.
You mentioned sewing-machines. Will it be necessary to make application to the Department or will you look after getting us some yourself? Likewise in the matter of things useful for the pupils. As requisitions are not sent in till May and we begin in March, what ought we to do? This is one of the reasons why I should like you to visit us at the beginning of our school year.

The Reverend Father Sirois expressed himself as much delighted with the interview he had with you. I am glad of it, for, in spite of all that we told him, he had his misgivings. It is homesickness ... as you said when you were here, but this long letter will prove that I am cured. I must conclude.

Assuring you of our entire collaboration in your work of education among the Indians, we are, etc.

(sgd.) Les Soeurs de N.-D. du Bon-Conseil per Sister Sainte Jeanne,
Superior.
Ottawa, November 9, 1944.

Reverend Sister Superior:

I have great pleasure in reading your report on the closing school term. It is gratifying to notice that the children are taking interest and pleasure in school activities.

I am also pleased to notice the enthusiasm which you demonstrate in your work. Your desire to take the extra courses is sufficient proof to that effect. Social welfare is no doubt one of the main problems which we have to face on the reserves.

As regards the sewing machines, they will be sent as soon as navigation opens in the spring. It might be well for you to send us a requisition at that time. We will also send a spinning wheel. As circumstances justify, we will in time supply you with small looms.

You might send in the requisition for school supplies any time after the closing of the school, in order that this material may be sent in time for the opening of the new term.

It is through co-operation that good, lasting work can be accomplished. Co-operation between the teachers, the teachers, school officials and religious authorities. I therefore, thank you for your assurance.
of co-operation in this difficult work of better education for the Indians.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I received the enclosed letter from Reverend Father Langlois, O.M.I., who, as you know, is in charge of Bethsiamits Mission (Bersimis).

As the matters complained of can apparently be remedied without much expenditure, I hope that you will be able to attend to them as soon as possible.

The matter of a residential school for this large Reserve should also be taken into immediate consideration. It is true that quite a number of children can attend a day-school but there is a much larger number, if the information which I have is trustworthy, whose parents trap and hunt in the Northern wilderness of Quebec and whose children cannot, therefore, attend a day school regularly.

According to the Day-School Census of 1936, which is the last one published, the average attendance at the Bethsiamits school was 38 and the total enrolment 69. The 1944 Census give 97 children of school age for this Reserve. Although this figure seems much smaller than the average children on reserves, as it is less than 1/6th of the total population, it would still leave 2/3rds of those children without any education.

Sir:

The Bersimis school will open on the first of March. On this occasion, the Principal of the school has drawn my attention to the conditions at this school and I thought that it was my duty to let you know the situation which I have verified personally.

The classroom supplies for which a requisition was sent last September have not arrived. We will, however, try our best to get along for some time with what remains from last year; but this will not suffice and will last only a short time; it would be necessary for the material requisitioned to arrive soon if education is not to suffer.

Exterior and interior repairs of a serious nature should be done to the building.

The water system in the rooms has been out of order for the last five years. Water has to be transported in pails in order that the toilets may be used. Mr. Blouin and his predecessor were notified of this condition but have done nothing to remedy it.

The plaster from the walls has fallen from a dozen places; the laths are now exposed. In several places the plaster has cracked and threatens to fall.

Since about twenty years the floors have not been repainted nor have the desks been revarnished.
At the exterior the humidity and the cold have destroyed the mortar which is falling from between the bricks of the chimney, and even the walls. The chimney could become dangerous if it is not repaired soon. It will be necessary to repoint the joints at several places.

The wood of the porch is also rotten and should be renewed.

I am sorry to send in these complaints as I know that you are very busy, but as you are soon to give us a new Agent, I thought that I ought to bring this situation to your attention in order to facilitate the work of this Agent and also that it will enable you to bring about a prompt remedy.

Yours truly,

Honorable Sir,

During the middle of May, I had occasion to visit Ottawa and interview the Director of the Branch of Indian Affairs, regarding the education and welfare of the Indians of Bersimis and Seven Islands, who have been confided to the missionary care of the Reverend Oblate Fathers by his Excellency Mgr Labrie, of Havre St-Pierre, P.Q.

I pointed out to Mr. Hoey that the Indians of Seven Islands had no school facilities whatsoever and that their number was close to 700. I further remarked that although there is a seasonal school for the Indians of Bersimis, only 53 of them are enrolled. The Indians of this latter reserve are trappers and loggers and living the year round, except for a very short time during the summer, away from the Bersimis village and therefore the school.

The only method, in my estimation, of educating these children would be the residential school and I have written to Mr. Hoey in that sense. I do hope, dear Sir, that when this question is placed before you for your consideration, you will act favourably upon it. May I mention that the Indians of Quebec have been very sadly neglected in matters of education, by the Department and that you will wish, I have no doubt, to correct the situation. It is rather sad to have to admit that over two-thirds of the Indians of that province are without education facilities.

I, therefore, hope that this matter will receive your serious attention and favourable consideration.

Very truly yours

(Sgd.) Paul Langlois O.M.I.

I may well answer this question by accusing myself of not asking enough. But presently, I confess that, in a country like Canada, such conditions should not exist. It is time for us all to bring together all our good will and try to improve the living standard for these poor people.

May I recall to your attention that all the Indians in this county of Saguenay are Catholic. A religious congregation for the school and hospital would be the ideal solution of the problem.

July 18th, 1946.

Honorable Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 26th, written by Mr. James A. MacKinnon, acting Minister and I apologize for not having answered sooner.

In Mr. MacKinnon's reply, it is said and I quote:

"There seems to be a wide-spread belief on the part of the general public and of the Indians themselves that the Indian day schools equipped for vocational instruction are on the whole more satisfactory and more efficient than residential schools".

May I be permitted to ask: can general public be taken as judge in such a particular case? General public does not know much of the Indian, his real life, his way of thinking, his mentality and his true needs. So how can one judge of a thing that he does not know sufficiently, but only from a few appearances?

There are so many things to consider in the necessity of establishing a boarding school for the Indians; to give a sound judgment general public would have to know whether the Indians would get more advantage physically intellectually and morally from a day school than from a residential school. I do not think general public can know that sufficiently.

Even the Indians themselves very often cannot judge of the thing for the same reason. Also I would add this other reason. I have not at all the intention of depreciating them by saying so; but the facts show that they have a good or bad opinion of a thing from the good or bad impression they have of it, at that moment; it depends on how they are impressed then. In the case of the residential school, it requires from them some sacrifices, and especially that of going into the bush and leaving their children into the school. So this sacrifice will influence very much sometimes their opinion about the residential school.
As for the vocational instruction in the day school, I cannot see why the residential school could not be equipped for such purpose as well as a day school; so with the benefit of the boarding school, the children would get that of the vocational training.

As Missionary I have been with the Indians for 17 years; I have spent seven years as principal of the Albany Residential School, in James Bay. Here, there is only a day school. I had seen the difference of both kinds of school in the Bay and I notice the same thing here: there is, for the Indian, much more advantages physically, intellectually and morally in the residential school than in the day school.

I, therefore, hope that this matter will receive favourable consideration.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) P. Langlois, O.M.I.

The Honourable J. Allison Glen,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Doucet,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 12 last, for which I thank you. I could not reply sooner because I was expecting a second reply from His Excellency Mgr Labrie, which reached me Friday last only.

I learned, last Friday, that His Excellency was at Baie Comeau and was to leave the next morning; I therefore took a taxi to go to interview him. He had first answered by telegram that he had accepted the changes proposed in my preceding letter, but as he did not propose the changes suggested by you, I tried to communicate with him again by telegram in order to be assured of his new acceptance although I was led to believe that he was not to change his mind and that he would abide by his decision.

He is well pleased with the last change, that is that the pupils be granted two months holidays, from August 15 to October 15, as we had decided, and everybody is satisfied. It is therefore understood that the children will leave for their vacation on August 15 next. This will allow them to go picking blueberries without being absent from school.

I thank you for the investigation you have made in order to get a toilet box. We shall wait.

You had promised to send us a gun to fill the joints between the bricks and around the windows where it is needed, as well as five or six gallons of gray cement. We have received nothing yet; was it lost or forgotten? It would be too bad if the joints were not filled now because this work would mean saving of coal next Winter. The twenty-five tons of coal have not yet arrived.

We will have performed the plumbing work requested, next month; our man is alone presently.

Honorable Sir:

I beg to express my thanks for the kindness you showed me on the occasion of my visit. I came back with a greater confidence for the welfare and education of our Indians.

May I be permitted to recall to your memory the object of this visit? It is a fact that our North Shore Indians have been neglected for many years. Their education very scant attention.

I insist again upon the necessity of a residential school in Seven Islands and, later on in Betsiamits.

We must take for granted that conditions of life have changed for Indians as well as for other people. We must therefore try to prepare them by education for more radical changes in the future that would upset all their moral and physical life if they are not prepared.

Knowing how deep is your sense of responsibilities I remain confident that you will not fail to have this important question investigated thoroughly.

With my thanks, I beg to express my most sincere and profound esteem.

Dear Sir,

The Indian day school was reopened on October 15th, 1947 as scheduled. The number of children attending the school is at present 81 but should reach about 100 in a few days as some families that were away for the last two months will be back to the village for the winter.

I have been told that last year there was only two Teachers but I really think they need a third one and I do not know who authorizes that, but I remember last July when Mr. Doucet the Inspector for the Education was down the Coast, he was supposed to go to Chicoutimi to make the necessary arrangements to have another Teacher and I never heard anymore about it, although I was under the impression that the extra one would be teaching the Canadian children.

I am also enclosing a Requisition sent from this Office on September 10th, and a letter from Mr. Philip Phelan for your information. We would need that Teacher's Desk and Chair if shipment can be made now.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY,

Bersimis Indian Day School.

The repairs carried out at this school made a great deal of improvement. There remains, however, some work to be done on the kitchen ceiling which apparently will not hold plaster for some reason or other. This ceiling could be covered with gyproc. This I feel confident would remedy the difficulty. I believe that the contractor in charge of building on this Reserve could handle this very efficiently and the cost should not exceed $75.00.

It had been recommended several years ago to increase the toilet facilities as there are only two toilets for approximately one hundred pupils. This recommendation, however, was never carried out, due possibly to the difficulty in obtaining fixtures. The addition of two fixtures would greatly improve, although would still be inadequate for the number of pupils in this school. It would take an addition of four fixtures to bring this up to the minimum.

It must be remembered that plumbing repairs in this section are rather difficult to achieve because all trained help and labour must be brought in from Bay Comeau or even Rimouski. However, the present building overseer appears to have quite a knowledge of this work and possibly he could undertake this improvement. The Agent should be asked to investigate the possibility of obtaining prices for these repairs.
I had an opportunity of visiting all three classrooms for a short time. I must say that the improvement since I visited this school for the first time six or seven years ago, has been very great. Some radical changes that were suggested at that time have produced dividends. However, I feel that this school has progressed as much as it is able to under the present teachers. I am satisfied that the teacher who is teaching seventh grade is attempting something above her capacity. This matter should probably be taken up with the Bishop and a definite change should be made. Our range of salaries should assure us fully qualified teachers to carry out the training that we are attempting for the people living in this locality.

I was unable to visit the Pastor as he was absent. However, I had a short talk with his Assistant. I did not deem it feasible, however, to discuss the standards of the school at that time.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

I had an opportunity of visiting all three classrooms for a short time. I must say that the improvement since I visited this school for the first time six or seven years ago, has been very great. Some radical changes that were suggested at that time have produced dividends. However, I feel that this school has progressed as much as it is able to under the present teachers. I am satisfied that the teacher who is teaching seventh grade is attempting something above her capacity. This matter should probably be taken up with the Bishop and a definite change should be made. Our range of salaries should assure us fully qualified teachers to carry out the training that we are attempting for the people living in this locality.

I was unable to visit the Pastor as he was absent. However, I had a short talk with his Assistant. I did not deem it necessary, however, to discuss the standards of the school at that time.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

April 12th, 1949

We, the undersigned, Chief and Councillors of the BERSIMIS Band of Indians owning the Reserve situated at BERSIMIS, in the BERSIMIS Indian Agency, in the Province of QUEBEC at a council summoned for the purpose, according to the rules of the Band, and held on the said Reserve, this TWELVETH day of APRIL, A.D. 1949, in the presence of the Indian Agent for the said Reserve, representing thereat the Minister of Mines and Resources for the Dominion of Canada;

Do hereby for ourselves, and on behalf of the Indian owners of the said Reserve, request:

THAT FOR THE BENEFIT OF ALL THE PUPILS ATTENDING THE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL IN BERSIMIS THE CLOSING DATE OF THE SCHOOL SHOULD BE CHANGED FROM AUGUST 15th TO THE END OF JUNE AS ALL THE OTHER SCHOOLS IN THE PROVINCE OF QUEBEC.

ONLY A FEW FAMILIES RESIDING IN THE BERSIMIS RESERVE ARE STILL GOING IN THE WOODS FOR HUNTING AND TAKING THEIR CHILDREN WITH THEM SO WE FEEL THAT WHILE THE OLDEST PUPILS MAKING THEIR SEVENTH GRADE THIS YEAR WE SHOULD CHANGE THE CLOSING DATE TO PERMIT THEM TO PASS THE EXAMINATION SO THEY COULD BE ALLOWED IN OTHER SCHOOLS NEXT SEPTEMBER TO CONTINUE THEIR EIGHTH GRADE SPECIALLY IF WE DO NOT HAVE THAT GRADE TAUGHT HERE IN BERSIMIS NEXT YEAR.

Signed and sealed in the presence of J.M. Ferland.

We have your letter of the 14th instant suggesting that the opening and closing dates of the Bersimis Indian Day School should be changed to conform with the dates in effect at Provincial White schools.

The dates on which the school has opened and closed in recent years were settled after considerable discussion and I believe Mr. Doucet visited the Agency and he also decided that the dates on which we have been operating were most satisfactory for all parties concerned.

I have reviewed the reports submitted by the Principal of the school regarding the enrolment and average attendance and it is found that the enrolment in July of 1948 was 121 and the average attendance 120. Betsiamits, Que. June 18th, 1949

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Booth Building,
Ottawa, Ont.

After discussing the question with the local Missionary and the Sisters regarding the closing date of the Indian Day School at Betsiamits, we came to the decision that it was better for this year to keep the School open until the 15th of August as in the previous years.

I understand that there will be very few families going in the Woods next winter as they are not getting any furs and cannot leave on it, so if it is the case next year we will communicate with you and then the date probably could be change.

The Council unanimously are still of the same idea that it is too hot in the classroom during the Summer months for all the children to attend school regularly but I have shown to them that only about half of the Pupils were attending the School regularly all winter and that it was our duty to see that the children would at least take advantage of the months of June, July and part of August.

Therefore the School will not close before the 15th. of August this year and we will follow your instructions.

J. M. Ferland, Supt.,
Bersimis Indian Agency.

Ottawa, November 20, 1923.

Sir,

The Department has not yet received the September quarter return of the Bersimis Indian Day School and, as a result, the salary and bonus due the teachers for that month have not yet been paid.

You should request the principal to at once prepare and forward, through your office, the return for the September quarter.

For your information I would say that the return from this school should be prepared promptly at the end of each quarter and forwarded to the Department by you.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

A. W. Powers, Esq., M. D.,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis,
QUE.

Ottawa, June 4th, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, informing the Department that the Bersimis Indian Day School would re-open today, and that the two former teachers, viz: Sisters St. Raphael and St. Eugene, would return and take up duties.

As you were informed in official letter of March 6th, last, the salaries will be the same as formerly paid, viz: $450 per annum to the teacher of the senior pupils and $350 per annum to the teacher of the junior pupils, both salaries to be supplemented by any bonus that may be provided by law.

It is hoped that there will be a regular attendance of all the Indian children of school age, and that the teachers will meet with success in their work.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. W. Powers, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis, P.Q.

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, we will allow salary at the rate of $100.00 a month for the Principal and $90.00 a month for her assistant at the Bersimis Indian Day School, effective October 15, 1946. It is understood that qualified teachers will be sent to the Bersimis School.

When Mr. Doucet visited Bersimis recently it was agreed by those interested that in future the Bersimis School would operate on a 10 month basis. It was also decided that the seasonal school at present in operation would close on August 15, 1946, as following this date many of the Indians leave the reserve. The regular academic year, in future will therefore extend from October 15 to the subsequent August 15.

Please advise Reverend Paul Langlois, O.M.I., regarding the above and arrange with him to let us know the names of the teachers as soon as they begin duties in October.

Yours sincerely,

For Deputy Minister.

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Ottawa, July 14th, 1919.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott: SCHOOL: BERSIMIS RESERVE.

The present school building on the Bersimis Reserve is the property of the R.C. Mission although the Department have provided school furniture and paid for the cost of certain interior alterations.

In company with Inspector Parker and Indian Agent Bosse I made a visit to the school and went carefully over the whole building.

The building has a cubic foot capacity of 4000 cu.ft. or sufficient for 16 pupils whereas there are 103 children of school age on the Reserve, 85 of whom were on the regular school roll during the summer quarter of last year.

I submit that in justice to the Indians, if the requirements of education are to be met, a school should be provided for the accommodation of at least 90 children having a cubic capacity of at least 22,000 cu.feet. This would entail the construction of a building 60 ft X 35 ft divided into two class-rooms of 11,000 cu.ft. capacity each.

In company with the priest in charge of the mission, Inspector Parker and the Indian Agent we tentatively looked over the ground for a suitable site and agreed that an excellent situation would be just west of the present school building where there is not only ample space for the new school building itself, but also desirable large space for a playground.

I would estimate the cost of such school after preliminary discussion with Mr. Ogilvie at $15,000 and if this amount is to be expended from the capital of the Indians, their consent will have to be secured.

I would suggest that as all the Indians will be at the Reserve on August 13th to receive their 10% distribution of the bonus from sale of timber, the question be submitted to them at that time, and that in the meantime tentative plans for the building be submitted so that the Department may be in a position to at least commence foundation and exterior work during the present year.
I would suggest that the cost of construction will be appreciably lessened if the contract is let this year, as a building contractor is on the Reserve there now with all the necessary equipment and men and that if the type of construction is brick, the building would be more permanent, fire-proof and almost as cheap as lumber.

I would recommend that tenders be called for not later than September 15th next.
MEMORANDUM.

Honourable Arthur Meighen.

School: Bersimis Reserve.

The present school building is the property of the Mission and has accommodation for only 16 pupils, whereas there are 85 scholars on the school roll and a population of 103 children of school age.

It is therefore proposed to re-model the interior of the present school building in order to make it suitable for a small hospital and home for aged Indians, and to construct a new school with sufficient capacity for the requirements.

I would recommend for your approval, the above plan of action as being of great benefit to the Indians and judicious expenditure of a portion of their capital funds.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, regarding the condition of the kitchen stove in the Bercimis Indian Day School. In reply, I beg to say that, if it is not possible to make repairs to the stove without unnecessary expense, it is considered that it would be better to purchase a new stove.

If you decide to purchase a new stove, you should obtain competitive prices and purchase a stove suitable for the requirements, from the firm quoting you the lowest price. If, however, you consider the present stove can be repaired, and a new fire-box obtained, you may have this work done.

In the purchase of any material, and labour required, the expenditure should be kept down to the lowest possible point. MEMO.

Sir,

We have had this winter at the Bersimis Day School a lot of trouble with the sewerage system. In the fall of 1920 before my arrival the cesspool was repaired and I found that it was put in a bad place. Last winter we had a lot of snow and it saved the piping from freezing but this winter it did freeze about the month of January and consequently the Sister were left without any sewerage system. Of course I could not at the time get the work started over again as the season was quite advanced and besides the work was nearly completed, and I thought it would be better to leave it as it was till something wrong developed.

The well would also need to be deepened some three or four feet.

The whole work of digging a new cesspool and deepening the well would entail an expenditure of about $60. to $70.

The piping in the sewerage system would still be good to use.

An early answer would be appreciated so as to get the work under way as soon as the ground thaws out.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.
