Ottawa, April 15th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th ultimo regarding the proposal to erect a boarding school and home on the Terrimine Reserve and in reply to state that the Department has had under consideration for some time the question of the establishment of a new school and hospital with doctor's office.

It is thought that the Department would not be justified in establishing a boarding school on the Reserve at the present time but as it is realized that there is urgent need for a new day school which would have adequate accommodation for the number of children of school age in the Reserve and also for a hospital or doctor's office where patients suffering from contagious diseases might receive treatment, the Department has now under consideration a proposal to erect a new school and re-model the present school so as to make it suitable for a hospital.

As you are aware the present school building is the property of the Catholic Mission and the Department paying an annual rent of $200 for the use of the building. I have no reason to believe that the Mission would be agreeable to disposing of this building to the Department and what value they would place thereon.

A new school built of brick and with a capacity for 90 children would cost approximately $15,000 and I would ask that you interview the Indians and determine if they would be willing to have this amount expended from their funds.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Memo to the Deputy Minister.

Bersimis Hospital & School.

In accordance with instructions I visited the Bersimis Reserve for the purpose of examining into the question of the construction of a school of sufficient size for the needs of the Indians, and that of making arrangements with the Eudiste mission for the use of the present school building for a hospital and doctor's office.

These two matters were discussed fully at a meeting of the band called for that purpose and in the presence of the missionary in charge, the Indian Agent and myself. The Indians by a unanimous vote decided to petition the Department to expend the sum of $20,000 for the construction of a brick day school sufficiently large for the reception of 100 scholars, and this petition was duly drawn up, signed by the Chief and three principal men, and witnessed by the Missionary in charge, the Indian Agent and myself. The petition itself is attached.

The Indians previously in the year 1919 petitioned the Department to expend the sum of $5,000 for the purpose of providing a hospital for the aged Indians who were physically unable to go hunting and for those suffering from illness who could not be treated in their homes.

This document is also on this file. See under.

The whole question of the necessity of providing a proper school and hospital has been dealt with in my memos. of July 14th, 1919 and April 30th, 1922 on this file and I would therefore recommend that the wishes of the Indians in these matters be given favorable consideration, and action taken as early as possible.

Whilst at Bersimis I staked out an excellent site for the proposed brick school, with the concurrence of the priest in charge, Father Jauffret, and Monseigneur Leveztoux the Catholic Bishop of the Diocese. The site adjoins the present frame building and comprises about two acres of land in all, so that there will be ample space for school grounds. A sketch plan is submitted herewith showing the exact site. The question of compensation to the mission for the use of the land, which has been under improvement for about thirty years was fully discussed with the Bishop and Priest. They expressed the opinion that the value of improvements on the land should be worth $500 but I pointed out that in all probability the Department would consider this an excessive price. The mission are unable to give title to the land, having merely been occupants of it and in consequence I proposed that the Department should occupy the site and the question of allowing some compensation should be left for future discussion. This was presented to.
The question of providing a hospital and doctor's office presented some difficulty at first. The present school building which is of frame construction was built some 15 years ago and the Department has leased it at a rental of $200 besides from time to time undertaking the cost of improvements such as repairs to fence and roof.

The building is owned by the Mission and the Bishop placed a value of $3500 on the building and contents. I pointed out that as the building was old, and as the Department had been responsible for keeping it in repair for a number of years besides paying an annual rental for the use of it, I was inclined to the opinion that this sum was quite out of proportion to the assessed value. After some discussion I suggested that the Department should continue to pay rental for the building but on the condition that such alterations might be made by the Department as were considered necessary to make the building suitable for the purpose intended, i.e., hospital and doctors' office.

Both the mission and the Bishop assented to this, and are prepared to give confirmation of this arrangement in writing if considered necessary.

This is in my opinion much the better arrangement, as it relieves the Department of a heavy initial expense and avoids an outright purchase of an old frame building.

I submit a blue print photograph of the present building, and a blue print plan showing front view, side view, ground floor, second floor and basement. I secured this plan from the official records of the agent and this will doubtless be of material assistance in deciding as to the requisite alterations.

With regard to the question of providing the necessary funds for the two buildings as asked for by the Indians, I may point out that in 1919 the Minister approved of the expenditure for these purposes, and I would therefore suggest that the necessary Order in Council be secured so as to enable work to be commenced next spring.

In conclusion I would like to point out that the Indians all expressed themselves as being very pleased with the manner in which their affairs are being looked after and that I am very grateful myself for the enthusiastic cooperation of the Indian Chief, the missionary in charge, the Bishop of the diocese and the Indian Agent.

The Report to Council herewith recommends expenditures from Bersimis Band capital of $20,000. on the construction of a new school-house, and $5,000. on converting the old school-house into a hospital, on the reserve in Saguenay County, P.Q.

The Dept. has had under consideration for some years the question of providing a new school-house on the Bersimis Reserve.

The old school-house, which belongs to the Hudiste R.C. Mission, and for which the Dept. pays an annual rental of $200. has accommodation for only 16 pupils. There are over 100 children on the reserve, 80 of whom are on the school enrollment, with an average attendance last quarter of 42. The Dept. considers that there should be accommodation for 100 pupils. The Indians have requested that a school-house large enough for the needs of the Band be erected, for which they are willing to spend $20,000. from their capital. An officer of the Dept. visited the reserve last month, and located a suitable site for the school on the reserve.

A hospital is needed for the sick and aged who are unable to go hunting, and in which the physician could have his office. For this purpose it is proposed to fix up the old school-house, and the Indians have passed a resolution to spend $5,000.

MR. ORR:

Plans and specifications were prepared for a new combined day school and teachers' residence required on the Bersimis Indian Reserve in Quebec. Outside brick veneering to be changed for spruce clap-boards,
Hot water heating system to be changed to a warm air system, utilizing three warm air furnaces,
and Mr. Amyot has advised that he is prepared to deduct the sum of $4,000.00, providing these changes are made. Sir,

I beg to inform the Dept. that Mr Amyot, the contractor of the new school, has started work.

As he was pointing out to me and as I discussed with Mr Bury, on his last visit to the Reserve, the grounds on which the School is being built is crossed by a small creek, and in order to check the flow of same during the spring freshets, and protecting the foundations of the building, same will have to be diverted, and a new ditch dug and 100 ft of 18-inch drain pipe to take care of the flow will have to be put in and same be covered up so as not to be in the way for play-yard for the pupils.

Mr Amyot and I went over the matter and he estimates the whole cost of fixing same at about $500.00

Now this matter is delaying the work and I would appreciate if the Dept. would forward authority to go ahead on this so as to hurry the construction. The excavation is about half done and the earth for the other half will be used to fill the present creek.

Mr Bury is well aware of the conditions of the grounds and you might refer to him, if possible. But as said before an immediate answer is desirable.

Yours truly,

(Alt. Powers, M.D.)

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
In reference to letter hereunder from agent Dr. Powers regarding the necessity of diverting a small creek which crosses the school grounds so as to permit of ample room for school foundation I discussed this matter with the agent when we selected the site, but decided to leave the matter in abeyance until the contractor got on the ground and looked over himself.

Dr. Powers now reports that it will be necessary to have this creek diverted and replaced with 100 feet of 18 inch covered drain pipe at an approx. cost of $500. I would recommend that as this is the only suitable site for the school and as the cost of diversion of creek is not excessive, such cost be authorised as an extra on the school contract.

Sir,

I have just been interviewed by Mr Amyot, contractor of the New School, on the question of the brick for the outside finish of the building.

He has shown me samples of the brick, which is called for by the contract, viz., an ordinary clay brick, and also a sample of pressed brick.

The difference between the two is very noticeable, and taking into consideration the building now under construction, which will be one of the sights of the Reserve, I would strongly recommend the use of the pressed brick instead of the ordinary clay brick, which has a rough surface.

Of course there is a difference in price, which the Dept. can very easily find out from its architect, through Mr Amyot the contractor.

I would strongly recommend that the above be duly taken into consideration and early advice on same would oblige,

Ottawa, Nov. 16, 1928.

Dear Sir:

This Department is now erecting a combined school and teachers' residence at Bersimis, Que., which will be completed about the end of December next.

As there will be no ferry at that time across the St. Lawrence to Rimouski some of the men actually employed on this work who are residing in towns south of Quebec are not willing to remain on this job after the last trip of the ferry boat, for fear of being compelled to drive upon their return a distance of 125 miles to the nearest railway station, which would mean a six days' journey and a lot of hardship and expense to them.

In view of the importance of having this government school completed this year, would it not be possible to arrange with your Department to have one of the Government boats, which travels between Quebec and the Lower St. Lawrence ports call at Bersimis on one of its return trips to Quebec next month and allow the seven or eight men to take passage on this boat as far as the nearest railway station or Quebec.

It is understood that all expenses incurred by these men during the trip would be refunded to your Department.

I would greatly appreciate it if you would advise me at any early date as to your decision in regard to this matter.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General

Dear Mr. McLean:

Your letter of the 16th instant, asking if this Department could arrange to take off from Bersimis by Departmental steamer workmen who are engaged there in building an Indian school, was delivered in person by Mr. Chene of your Department accompanied by Mr. LeBlanc.

As I understood Mr. LeBlanc was leaving for Quebec I advised him to go and see our Agent there, Mr. T. Beland, who would advise him of the probable dates we would have a Departmental steamer in the vicinity of Bersimis.

Mr. Beland is in Ottawa today and on taking the matter up further with him he advised me that the "MONTGAL" should have left Quebec this morning on a trip to the lower part of the river for the purpose of removing the buoys at Manikungan, which is near Bersimis. This, I expect will be the last trip of one of this Department's steamers to that locality, but, if the weather were suitable, I think arrangements could be made to send our pilot tender across from Father Point when she is leaving her station which will likely be early in December.

TRANSLATION

Ottawa, November 18th, 1923.

Dear Mr. d'Anjou:

In reply to your telegram dated the 3rd of November, and to confirm the results of our interview with the Honourable Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, concerning the acquisition by this Department of a certain number of electric machines belonging to the Reverend Ursuline Sisters of Rimouski, Que., I regret to say that the examination of these apparatus has shown that they were of too great capacity to be adopted for the electric lighting system of the Bersimis, Que., where a few lamps only will be used, seeing that that school will be occupied by the Reverend Sisters teaching solely and will not be used as a boarding school.

I wish to say, however, that I will do everything possible to facilitate the purchase of these machines at the first occasion when required for one of the institutions under the direction of this Department.

In the meantime it would be well for the proprietors of these machines to send me a complete and detailed list of the apparatus above mentioned, together with the price of each one in particular.

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Superintendent General

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 4th instant, I beg to say it is necessary that the fire be kept going in the Bersimis School at all times during the winter. If the same should be allowed to go out the entire system would freeze up and destroy the heating plant. Consequently, you may make temporary arrangements to secure a competent man to look after the heating plant. CANADA
Sir,

Referring to your letter of November 15th last, No 3-1-5, I beg to transmit herewith vouchers in duplicate in favor of Mr A.A. Amyot for work performed digging open well, and digging drainage, and supplying materials in connection with same for the new Bersimis Indian Day School.

The accounts of Mr Bellavance, Rousseau, and Imperial Oil are not in duplicate as Mr Amyot forgot to get same in duplicate not being aware of the fact.

To the amount of these vouchers will have to be added the drainage pipes, and different materials which were bought by Mr A. Leblanc, and the invoices of which I have not on hand, and which I presume Mr Leblanc himself must have produced at the Department.

I did not make the total as I do not know what percentage the Dept. allows to Mr Amyot for the work.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
OTTAWA, JAN. 23, 1924.

SEND the following NIGHT LETTER subject to the terms on the back hereof, which are hereby agreed to:

Alf. Powers, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis, Que.

RE-BERSIMIS SCHOOL CONTRACT.

Advise by wire if building completed satisfactorily in accordance with plans, specifications, and to your satisfaction STOP If so final payment shall be issued to contractor.

J. D. McLEAN,
Chg. Indian Affairs.
DEPT INDIANS AFFAIRS OTTAWA ONT

RE SCHOOL CONTRACT ABOUT TEN DAYS MORE PAINTING TO COMPLETE UNDER MY SUPERVISION EXPLANATORY LETTER FOLLOWS

DR ALFRED POWERS.

USE OUR DIRECT ALL-CANADA SERVICE TO VANCOUVER, VICTORIA AND BRITISH COLUMBIA
Sir,

In answer to your letter of December 17th/23 re outbuilding in connection with the new Bersimis Day School, I beg to reenclose plan as requested, and must say that this plan is altogether desirable, and that the question of building the wood-shed as a lean-to would be very well if the saving in difference would be worth while, as the utility of same would in no way be impaired, if it was decided to build it as a lean-to.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir,

With reference to your No 3-1-5 dated Dec. 13th last, I beg to say that I have interviewed Georges Rock who is looking after the furnace at the hospital, which is also a hot-water system, and with an additional $5.00 per month, to what he already receives for the hospital, he will look after the School's furnace till the Spring when definite arrangements for the coming winter can be agreed upon. He is already looking after same since the 1st of January.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:-

In reply to your letter number 3-1-5 concerning the drum; I have it stored as Mr. Leblanc told me, and I will send it by the first crossing.

For the transport on board and the storage it amounts to three ($3.00) dollars. Believe me, Sir.

Yours, etc.,
